reviewText:
Since the times of Roberto Rosellini's "Germany year zero" and Rene Clement's "Forbidden games" the vision of WW2 under the childish perspective, had not achieved such level of profound candidness, innocence about the hellish landscape in which grew up.

A sensitive boy - Bruno -  who stems in superior grade the value of the friendship, is the son of a German officer, who is promoted to a new destiny in 1942. That superior decision makes they have to leave their home in Berlin to a rural house.

The smells, livings and memories of these ages will slowly be blurring, when this little man meets another Jewish child, dressed with pijama and numbered  prisoner. He is not informed at all what's going on behind that fence and ingenuously thinks they are farmers.

That weird friendship will be the cornerstone of a tragic fatality when a set of random circumstances lead that German father to taste the bitterness of that final solution.

Well acted and supported by an agile camera handle. Recommended without reserves.
All I can say about this movie is that it's sad, very emotional, some beautifu shots, and a very good sound track. The last 15 minutes everyone's hearts were pounding.

Certainly, there are some professional critics who will show-off clever epithets when they review this film.  Their smart-aleck comments might be something like "See what happens to naughty little boys who disobey their parents?" or, "Curiosity killed the cat."  There are some critics who opine that this film disserves the Holocaust.  Look, just avoid them, and see the film.

Such comments like those are unfair to the film, which hits the right note in its simplicity.  There are many directors who would've blown it way out of proportion.  Some commentators have criticized the actors' British dialects.  The use of dialects is part of the actor's craft.  However, I find the director's decision not to use German dialect appropriate.

I saw the movie in limited release without foreknowledge of the plot or the storyline.  I found it a haunting story that lingers in the mind.  The audience, with whom I saw it, did not cheer, did not applaud, and did not cry; we were just numbed into silence by the power of the story.  We exited in silence.  That doesn't happen in movies too often.  I can see the faith the studio has in it.  But having seen it once, do I want to see it again?

If viewed as a fable, and the book has won many awards, the story may be too simplistic.  The book was written for children, as if a child was to read the story, but it's marketed to young adults in high school, I think because of the story's power.  Using a fable to tell the story allows the author to take a step from reality.  Some have correctly commented upon the implausibility of the plot and events in the film.  Whether it was correct for the director to follow the book so closely, that is, telling an allegory or fairy tale (which cinema does poorly, as in the case of Spielberg's wonderful film, "AI: Artificial Intelligence" (2001)), is uncertain.  If the director had chosen to infect the film with some hard doses of reality, the film would have a different feel.

Consider, Bruno, the major character.  In the book and film, he's an eight-year old boy who is innocent of all the storm and stress of Nazi Era Germany.  In reality, Bruno would've been in the Hitler Youth since he was six.  He would've been educated in the Nazi catechism of the time and not been such an innocent in search of a playmate.  If, for the sake of the movie, Bruno was in the Hitler Youth and been shown in uniform for a moment, let's say at the party in Berlin, it might have meant a stronger character arc for him, reminiscent of the film, "Tomorrow the World" (1944) that starred Skippy Homeier, who won an award for his portrayal of a Hitler Youth.  The storyline would not need to change; the plot would proceed like Teutonic clockwork toward the powerful coda.  But, perhaps that might've changed it too much, for the film relies on its simplicity.

Consider, Shmeul, Bruno's acquaintance.  Shmeul's survival in the camp was very uncertain, but we know that children did survive.  We have recollections of those who were there.  At the end of the war, Allies had a terrific problem relocating the surviving children, as told in the film, "The Search" (1948).

But, that's the difference between telling a fable intended for children (who've been shooed away by the rating) and a fable for adults who see the childishly simple metaphors at play.

So, would I want to see this movie again?  Yes, I want to see it again, if I can afford it, and if I can get myself in the frame of mind again.  Do I recommend owning a copy of the video?  Yes.  I will, but not on Blu-ray.

I think this is a story that tells the affect of the Holocaust and its lingering Hell on everyone connected with it then and ever since, and I think it will affect you, too.

I just returned from taking 3 young boys(ages 9-11) to see this film.  They are all pretty mature and know a lot about the Holocaust already, but I think that this film made them realize the actual horror of the Holocaust in a way that books can't.  That the story is told through the eyes of a very precocious 8-year-old kept their interest, even though virtually all the film's violence is implied or happens off-screen. I had no idea the film ended as it did, and we all walked out in silence.  Yet, the more we discussed it on the way home, the more we saw the irony--well, perhaps poetic justice, in a sense-- of the film's message of evil and the way it takes root, and how you can't participate in it and still keep yourself and your family separate from it.  The message is transferable to so many modern situations that this alone makes the film worthwhile.  Yes, the boys' conversations would have been spotted very quickly--yes, the ending requires you to take a leap of logic...but the performances and the moral of the movie render it worthy of a viewing.  By the way, Vera Farmiga as Bruno's mother is superb.

You'd think it would be easy to determine how to feel about "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas," but no, it isn't. Despite the heavy subject matter, it tells such a simple, direct story, and there are virtually no gray areas in terms of character development. Everyone is defined so thoroughly at the start of the film that they never really have the chance to become something else, which is to say that there's no sense of maturation. I believe this also applies to the main character, an eight-year-old German boy named Bruno (Asa Butterfield), who at the height of Hitler's regime moves with his family from Berlin into the countryside. Their new home is directly next to a concentration camp, where an eight-year-old Jewish boy named Shmuel (Jack Scanlon) spends his time sitting at the electrified border. When Bruno goes exploring one day, he meets Shmuel, and even though they're separated, the two become friends. Despite the fact that Bruno learns a great deal over the course of the film, I'm hard pressed to say that he transitions from ignorance to knowledge. Quite simply, there's just so much he doesn't understand.

In all fairness, that's probably a much more realistic approach to the material. We've seen so many films that adhere to the "Amazing Grace" principle, in which characters are lost then found, blind then able to see. We get nothing like that from "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas." Bruno is incredibly ignorant, mostly because he grew up in a world that wanted to keep him that way. He hears and sees anti-Semitic propaganda all around him, and yet we're never really sure if he believes any of it. I say this because he's the kind of child that asks a lot of questions, most of which aren't answered satisfactorily; those that are answered inevitably lead to even more questions, which is a good thing because it proves he's actually thinking. His only problem is that he's never able to come to a conclusion. All he can do is keep wondering why certain things are the way they are. That may explain why he would much rather read an adventure story than a history textbook--daring explorers in fantasy worlds are much easier to understand.

Bruno is essentially the film's strongest element. Not so strong are most of the other characters, which are all so rigidly constructed. Bruno's father, Ralf (David Thewlis), is a strict Nazi soldier who oversees the neighboring concentration camp. Bruno's mother, Elsa (Vera Farmiga), spends much of the film is a blissful state of ignorance, aware that Jews are the enemy but blind to the fact that many are tortured and killed; even when she discovers why the smoke emanating from the camp's chimneys is so foul-smelling, she can do nothing but cry uncontrollably. Bruno's twelve-year-old sister, Gretel (Amber Beattie), is strong-headed and hopelessly brainwashed.

The rest of the supporting characters were never given the chance to fully develop, which is a shame considering the potential they all had. One is Bruno's grandmother (Sheila Hancock), who doesn't get along with her son because, apparently, she doesn't quite buy into Hitler's vision for a glorious future. Another is Lieutenant Kotler (Rupert Friend), a young Nazi soldier that Gretel has a crush on. The dramatic possibilities for this character were mostly overlooked, reducing him to little more than a passing reference. There are, in fact, only two supporting characters that work well. One is Shmuel, who, because of his age, is just as ignorant as Bruno; he knows that life is hard for him in the camp, but he has no real idea how things work under a Nazi regime. Another is Pavel (David Hayman), an imprisoned Jew who's often sent to work in Bruno's family's kitchen. When Bruno cuts his leg after falling off a handmade tire swing, Pavel tends to his wounds; when he tells Bruno that he used to practice as a doctor, Bruno fails to understand why a doctor would give that up to be a potato peeler.

His ignorance plays a vital role in the film's emotionally draining ending, which will no doubt divide audiences. There's no resolution--there's only a slow, agonizing fade to black. There's also the sickening feeling that, as far as the characters are concerned, absolutely nothing has been learned. There was an audible reaction amongst the people I saw this film with. As we all walked out of the theater, one woman behind me said, "What a disappointing ending." I was compelled to turn around and calmly ask her, "What more needed to be said?" The way I see it, the final scene of "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is perfectly acceptable; given the course of events, which I obviously can't describe, there would be no way to prolong the ending without it seeming forced.

As I said at the beginning, it isn't easy determining how to feel about this film. It's an above average story of friendship, and I was certainly moved a great deal by it. But it's not without its flaws, especially when it comes to character development. On the whole, I think it's fair to say that it's an unforgettable film, highly emotional and deeply thought provoking. "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" will not give everyone what they want, but that doesn't mean it doesn't say everything it needs to say. In other words, it tells a complete story. It doesn't, however, give us complete characters, which is clearly a disappointment given the powerful nature of the subject matter. And while only a minor thing, some may also be bothered by the fact that an entirely British cast portrays German characters. If seeing this movie depends on a single reason, let it be Asa Butterfield, who does a wonderful job as Bruno, a curious, nave young boy. Of all the characters, his was the most compelling.

What did the Holocaust look like through the eyes of Jewish children consigned to the concentration camps? Or through the eyes of an entirely normal Nazi family whose father was "promoted" from Berlin to Commandant of a death camp in the countryside? Bruno is only eight years old, so he's naturally curious about the "farm" only a few hundred yards from his family mansion, where people wear striped pajamas with numbers on them. Where black smoke billows from chimneys, and where horrid smells fill the air. And if Pavel was a doctor, why is he now wearing those pajamas and peeling potatoes for his family? Bruno forms an unlikely friendship through the electric barbed wire with another eight-year-old, Shmuel. The innocence that they share puts into bold relief the horrendous consequences of the Holocaust -- for the Jews, of course, but in unlikely and catastrophic ways for every member of this prim, proper, and patriotic family whose father was responsible for "making the world better." The film explores a horrible paradox of the Holocaust -- that an evil of unimaginable magnitude was carried out by everyday people just like us.

I have real mixed feelings about "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas", a new British film about a German boy and his family during World War II.

As I watched the film, directed by David Herman ("Brassed Off", "Little Voice") and co-produced by the BBC, I was carried along by the story, which is impossibly idealized. But the filmmakers do a clever thing and mask the idealization through the eyes of an 8-year-old boy, who doesn't, and probably couldn't, know the truth. But the more I think about it, is this a good thing? And who is the audience for this film?

Bruno (Asa Butterfield) is a pretty typical 8-year-old boy. He enjoys playing with his friends and finds the family's huge Berlin house to be fertile for his imagination; Bruno and his friends run through the hallways and up and down the staircase with abandon. Bruno's mom (Vera Farmiga, "The Departed", "Breaking and Entering") and dad (David Thewlis, the "Harry Potter" films) sit their children down and tell them about Father's new promotion, a promotion which means they must move to a new house in the country. Father is a German officer and his promotion has been to run a Concentration Camp. But Bruno and his older sister don't know this and they cautiously roam through the new house. Bruno spots a "farm" from his bedroom window and inquires about the "funny people" wearing striped pajamas. Mama is confused, but soon realizes what he has seen and quickly boards up his bedroom window. Desperate for some adventure, Bruno eventually sneaks into the back garden and further, moving through the lush plants and overgrown grass until he comes to the electrified fence surrounding the "farm". There, he spots a boy, Shmuel (Jack Scanlon) sitting on the other side of the fence, staring into his hands, and they talk. A friendship quickly blooms leading Bruno to try to get away everyday and sneak food to his new friend.

As Bruno runs through the fields, the director seems to have placed a filter on the lens to capture as much dappled sunlight as possible. This stretches the believability of the story quite a bit. But just as I felt myself about to switch off, I realized, or remembered that Bruno is only eight. His parents have kept him sheltered from the truth and he doesn't have any idea of what is going on.

But does this make it OK to watch such an idealized view of such a horrific event? Even such a small part of such a horrific event?

Obviously, this story isn't going to have a happy ending. But the extent of this ending shocked me and made the film more powerful erasing many doubts.

On the one hand, "Striped Pajamas" almost wants to be a bedtime story. On the other hand, it tries to tell a moving story that will tug at your heart, trying to get you to cry. But both efforts are just slightly off. When I researched the director, David Herman, and found that he had directed both "Brassed Off", starring Ewan McGregor and Pete Posthelwaite and "Little Voice" starring Brenda Blethyn and Michael Caine, some things clicked into place. Each of these films has various elements that work, but they are all slightly off. Like something isn't clicking into place. Like the director doesn't have enough skill to recognize there is a problem, or the skill to correct the problem and connect all of the dots. Each film is missing something to connect the dots.

There is an attempt to bring home the horrors of the situation. Mama (Farmiga) knows they are moving to a house on the outskirts of a concentration camp, she knows what her husband is about to undertake, but she doesn't realize the extent of the job. The moment of realization is powerful, but it comes early and is followed by a lot of erratic behavior. Mama also spends a lot of time frowning or looking worried as she realizes Bruno might eventually learn the truth or as she watches her daughter begin to embrace the Third Reich, joining the youth movement.

The behavior seems to have no effect on Bruno, because he doesn't know or understand what is going on.

Because the children are living in the country, Papa hires a tutor for them. We watch as the tutor attempts to teach the two kids the party line, instilling in them the propaganda leading to the horrors perpetrated by the Third Reich. At one point, Bruno spies on a secret meeting and watches a propaganda film about how great life in the camps is. These are very interesting moments, but they don't really seem to open up little Bruno's eyes. Since we are following Bruno through this journey, it is difficult for us to watch, as he doesn't seem to come to any realizations.

The main problem seems to be the choice of an 8 year old as our guide through this story. "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas" is aimed at adults who go to foreign films, adults who like Merchant Ivory films, adults who like historical period pieces. So why an 8 year old? Are the filmmakers trying to attract children? To make the film seem more like a bedtime story? I really don't think so, but you have to wonder. If any children of this age actually watch this film, I think they might have nightmares. When the story finally shifts and the events begin to become more horrific, the children will have questions. Questions that you will have to answer and the answers will most likely scare the children.

But the film doesn't exactly work as a story strictly for adults. Because Bruno never sees any of the consequences of what his father is doing, what his country is doing, he remains oblivious. It is almost as though the filmmakers want us to fill in the blanks, leaving the horror to our imagination. And this works to a certain extent, but because Bruno is our guide into this world, he needs to see some of this as well. When a friendly old Jew, a former doctor, who works in the house suddenly disappears, Bruno asks about him and his sister responds "He's not coming back" with an attitude indicating he should know better. We know better. But Bruno wouldn't.

But the filmmakers temper this lack of awareness in two ways. Bruno is very young. And his lack of realization leads him to a very problematic end.

Vera Farmiga is good as Mama. As soon as she realizes what is going on in the camp, she becomes emotionally troubled and can't accept what her husband is doing. Unfortunately, this leads her to sit around with red eyes, swing on a tire swing for hours, and to act like a crazy person, causing her husband a lot of problems. The role is a bit over the top and theatrical, but as she is the only person who seems to realize the horror, it works.

David Thewlis is also good as Papa, an officer in the German army who accepts his new promotion with pride. He shows a believable lack of emotion and a credible amount of stern authority. Thankfully, he plays the character pretty even keel, staying away from histrionics.

Even though the performances are good, this is yet another film set during World War II in which the majority of the characters speak with British accents. Yes, the film is directed by a Brit, and co-produced by the BBC. But try to go for some authenticity and make the characters at least sound like they are German. In the upcoming "Valkyrie", it appears that Tom Cruise doesn't attempt any accent along with all of his British co-stars.

"The Boy in The Striped Pajamas" suffers from an inconsistent, mixed message.

Historically speaking, the premise of this movie involves a good dose of suspension of belief as most small children who were victims of the holocaust would probably have been killed by the Nazis and their collaborators right away given the fact that they would not have been strong enough to do the hard labor that was required of most concentration camp prisoners. Add to that, the unlikelihood that a German boy (and the son of an SS officer) would have been able to come into such close contact with a concentration camp, let alone be able to repeatedly wander from home without his very protective mother being aware of it.

Even so, I think that if a movie is done well enough, if the characters and the plot are engrossing enough, and if the acting is exemplar, then sometimes the suspension of belief is warranted, and on some level, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas"  seems to do so. Indeed, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" at least is a good vehicle to engage young people into a conversation on the psychological aspects of genocide, the process of dehumanization, blaming the victim, and the mob mentality that might lead otherwise normal people into carrying out and supporting the horrific treatment of others. On the other hand, I would also advise the viewer who is new to the subject of the holocaust (as well as any teacher who plans on using "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" as a supplement to a study on the holocaust, Nazi Germany or World War II) that a classroom showing of this movie should be accompanied by a clarification that the REAL holocaust was about 100 times worse than what is shown of the holocaust in this movie (as bad as that seems).

In this sense, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is not as much about the victims of the holocaust as it is an exploration of the minds of the perpetrators.

While "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" did not seem to captivate me on a level that would live up to what friends of mine built it up to be, the movie did manage to hold my attention throughout. I just wish that there was a little more to the movie as conflicting feelings in the characters could have been explored on a deeper level. It deserves credit for sincere effort on a very challenging topic that is prone to controversy no matter how one chooses to frame it.

This review is in reference to the Blu-ray/Digital format combo of this product, not the movie itself.

As a teacher, I do not have DVD/Blu-ray players in my classroom. I needed to use two specific scenes from this movie in our holocaust unit (not even the entire movie). It's not available digitally from Amazon, so I purchased the combo. It is completely useless. The digital copy requires you to create an account with a third party, Vudu, which I wasn't crazy about, but did it anyway. The playback was pathetically slow (most likely attribute to our district's internet, but after this experience I won't rule our it being an issue on Vudu's side - especially since I stream video clips All. The. Time with absolutely no issues). At this point, I attempted to download the movie, but guess what? I would need to download Vudu's program to my laptop to do this. Not gonna happen. I purchased the movie for the sole purpose of being able to watch it digitally and this product does not allow me to do this without programs they force you to use and, of course, release your personal information to. I'm going to see if I can return it, but this is the last time I will ever purchase something like this. Teachers beware!

I haven't seen this on amazon but i saw it a few years ago. I have a good friend who is the grandson of the commandant of Auschwitz. I'm Jewish and so we always had this really colorful and weird (and oddly not that tense at all) friendship. And this movie reminded me of him a lot. Now from a filmmaking standpoint, it is no Schindler's List. It's more on par with Jacob the Liar (also a pretty good film)

Here is the issue I take with this film. It was created as if the family had 21st century sensibilities. The kids were not made aware of what was going on because dad wanted to, what? Protect them from his flagrant racism? To understand that this is kind of BS, you have to understand the time and place. These kids were not shielded from all this racism. They were told to embrace it and disciplined most severely if they didn't. So it's kind of hard to take this "protect my kid from what i know is wrong" nonsense seriously since this dude should have been knee high in the Hitler Youth by this age anyway.

But despite the plotholes, it's a great movie.

Loved it. My daughter wanted to watch this and I think I enjoyed it more than her.

This was a very well-played, well acted film about a subject we have seen and heard much about in the last 30 years or so, but not from this perspective. The actors chosen to be in the film were excellent, especially David Thewlis as the father and extermination camp commandant. Here was a case of someone who appeared to have lost his moral integrity and by the end of the movie he realizes to some extent what this has cost him. Asa Butterfield as his son is very good, considering how young he was when he made this picture. Asa has gone on to do many other pictures and I have enjoyed watching his career grow as he develops into a young adult. I won't give away the ending, except to say it is shocking even though you sense something like it is coming. I still would recommend this film, but only to viewers in their mid-teens or older, it would be too upsetting for young children to see in my opinion.

The 2008 holocaust period film The Boy in the Striped Pajamas had a tall order to fill. In a cinematic landscape deluged with films centered around the horrors of the holocaust, this film had to stand outto say something unique or else say the same old thing in a unique way. Using this criterion, it was only a partial success. Its speculation on what the dynamic of a family in the Third Reich divided over Nazi death camps might look like was intriguing. Not only that, but its focal point of two boys who just want to be friends despite the racial politics being thrust upon them gave a clear and simple gut level refutation of racism and violence. These positives are weakened more superficially by its heavy-handedness (the film's use of irony to hint to the mass killing of innocent Jewish people comes off almost like a series of badly conceived jokes) and more fatally by its unwillingness to grapple with issues of meaning and hope in light of humanity's inhumanity to man. The result is a film with great potential that ends up feeling gratuitous and nihilistic.

 While the metaphysical implications of the holocaust could be approached from a number of angles, this film's refusal to deal with the God question perhaps stands out as the most salient evidence of its need to be grounded in some kind of meta-narrative. The weight of the film's silence on this issue is felt when one considers the philosophical difficulty that inevitably arises in any serious reflection upon the holocaustwhere was God? Woody Allen's character in Anything Else, a paranoid Jewish school teacher named Dobel, points to this problem somewhat circuitously when he reasons, The crimes of the Nazis were so enormous . . . it would be justified if the entire human race were to vanish as a penalty. If the holocaust is such an indictment upon the human race, what does this tell us of God's responsibility? Does God care? If so, why not intervene? Was he trying to punish the Jewish people? As psychologist and holocaust survivor Victor Frankl mused, "If there is a meaning in life at all, then there must be a meaning in suffering. Suffering is an ineradicable part of life" (Frankl). It would be useful to examine how other media have dealt with this problem before returning to how The Boy in the Striped Pajamas deals (or doesn't deal) with it.

 One approach to this issue is the pessimistic one: perhaps God doesn't exist or else doesn't care about the suffering of Jews in the holocaust. The atheistic explication is given in another Allen filmCrime and Misdemeanors. At the scene of a Jewish dinner table, an atheist family member gets impatient with the customary Jewish blessing for food which quickly turns into an argument. The patriarch of the family, the atheist's brother, brings up the idea that God punishes the wicked. Like Hitler? his sister retorts. [The Nazis] got off with nothing because might makes right (Crimes and Misdemeanors).

 The perhaps more unsettling answer, that God exists but didn't care about the holocaust, is given voice in the film God on Trial wherein Jews in a concentration camp hold a trial to determine if God has broken His covenant with Israel. In the end, one man stands up and claims that since God supported the Jewish people in slaying their enemies, and their enemies are now slaying them, perhaps God has chosen the side of their enemies and established a new covenant with them.

 Rabbi Harold Kushner's popular book, When Bad Things Happen to Good People, makes a very different argument. Sure, God is loving. Of course He cared about the suffering of Jews at the hands of the Nazis. This being so, God would do what He could to help the Jewish people, but must not have been able to prevent it.

 Elie Wiesel's book Night, a memoir of his experience in a Nazi concentration camp, famously dealt with this question and gave the most creative answer to this difficulty:
Then came the march past the victims. The two men were no longer alive. Their tongues were hanging out, swollen and bluish. But the third rope was still moving: the child, too light, was still breathing... And so he remained for more than half an hour, lingering between life and death, writhing before our eyes. And we were forced to look at him at close range. He was still alive when I passed him. His tongue was still red, his eyes not yet extinguished.
Behind me, I heard the same man asking:
'For God's sake, where is God?'
And from within me, I heard a voice answer:
'Where He is? This is where--hanging here from this gallows...' (Wiesel).

 For Wiesel, God was identifying with the suffering of the Jewish people and it was His holy image being destroyed in the death camps. This answer perhaps found even greater depth in its explication by Jurgen Moltmann, a Christian theologian who pointed to God's taking on flesh in Christ to suffer alongside us as the epitome of the chosen passibility of a God who chooses to empathize with His image bearers. In The Crucified God, Moltmann argues for the supreme relevance of such a view:
Shattered and broken, the survivors of my generation were then returning from camps and hospitals to the lecture room. A theology which did not speak of God in the sight of the one who was abandoned and crucified would have had nothing to say to us then (Moltmann).

 In The Trinity and the Kingdom, he summarizes it: In their hearts all true men worship one God - the naked, wounded, bloody, but unconquered and unconquerable Christ (Moltmann). For Moltmann, suffering love is simply who God is. He cannot be absent in suffering, but is most present there. Such a view finds literary expression in Shusaku Endo's Silence, which tells the story of two Catholic priests investigating the alleged apostasy of a missionary to Japan. When they arrive in Japan and are taken by the Japanese government, they learn that the oppressor's tactic is to force the missionaries to apostatize at the threat of the lives of Japanese Christians. One of the priests, having struggled with the perceived silence of God in the face of human suffering, suddenly hears Christ speaking to him through an icon the priest is forced to trample on in order to save Japanese Christians from death: Trample! Trample! . . . It was to be trampled on by men that I came into the world. It was to share in men's suffering that I carried my cross (Endo).

 With all of these options to give a metaphysical framework to the holocaust, the Boy in the Striped Pajamas chooses none of them. In a post-modern age where the big questions are viewed as unanswerable since meaning is thought of as subjective, this isn't a surprise. If there is a moral appeal here it is based on the phenomenon of empathy, but why should empathy motivate my actions? There is suffering, sure, but what of it? The arbitrariness of a Nazi father putting Jewish children in gas chambers while trying to save his gentile son from one comes across quite strongly, but why should this stir viewers to act on behalf of humanity with love? Is our love as arbitrary as the Nazi father's hatred? If God doesn't exist or care, why should we care? If true art is meant to clarify values, which set of values is this film intending to impart? It seems to serve as a kind of fable or parable, but what precisely is its lesson and what undergirds its moral? In an age where the big questions are of little esteem, it is no surprise that The Boy in the Striped Pajamas feels shallow when its subject matter deserves the greatest depth of reflection which its creators can muster.

References
Herman, M. (Director). (2008). The Boy in the Striped Pajamas.
Allen, W. (Director). (2003). Anything else [Motion picture on DVD].
Frankl, V. E. (2006). Man's search for meaning.
Allen, W. (Director). (1989). Crimes and misdemeanors [Motion picture on VHS].
de Emmony, A (Director). (2008). God on trial.
Kushner, H. S. (1981). When bad things happen to good people. New York: Schocken Books.
Wiesel, E. (1960). Night.
Moltmann, J. (1974). The crucified God: The cross of Christ as the foundation and criticism of Christian theology.
Moltmann, J. (1981). The Trinity and the kingdom: The doctrine of God.
Endo, S. (1979). Silence.

My students read the Holocaust memoir, Night, and I needed a concentration camp video to show them the horrors of the Holocaust, without being way too over the top and graphic.  And then I remembered this movie (and the book).  I'd previously read the book and watched the movie too, so I knew what to expect in terms of the ending.  I did have students who were visably upset at the ending (no spoilers) but they all understood what had happened and why.  Most had grown attached to the characters of Bruno and Schmuel and were hoping for a happy ending, like in most of our in-class readings.  A great film that allows younger kids to understand the horrors of the Holocaust, without showing the dead bodies being pushed by bulldozers.

I could only give this movie 4 stars because I didn't like the ending. I don't like sad endings for one, and I also don't like being left hanging. It just ended. I hate it when movies do that.
Other than that I thought it was a really cool story, relative to the content of course. I liked the view from a child's perspective of what that time may have been like. It humanizes Germans. When horrible things like that occur it's easy to sit back and think that all Germans are terrible, but this movie brings to light that some of them were just children. Some of them were brainwashed (by that I don't mean tortured). Some of them were impressionable and young and they were taught crazy things like Jews were bad and they should all be killed. If everyone in your life is telling you that (parents, teachers, media, etc.) then it's kind of hard not to believe it.
Since I didn't see anything in the movie about how it was based on a true story (which it is not as far as I can tell) I don't think it's fair to judge this movie on the historical inaccuracies. It's called Historical Fiction for a reason. So, if you're looking for a movie about what really happened during the holocaust, go watch a historical documentary. This is a movie, based on a book that a guy a wrote. And while it is fiction, it does portray real, human emotions. I'm glad I got to watch this movie, but it is not one I will be buying, watching again or recommending to others.
Well done, sobering to think about

I appreciated that this movie is one that I can show my middle schooled kids, without the gore and "sexualized" scenes that come out of Hollywood that they would not be ready to face yet.

The perspective of every character is quite moving, how the father views the Jews, which is one of anger and a job.  The mother, even though she is passive and does nothing, is affected, reminding us all that if we do nothing of injustice, we will be perpetrated on one day. The daughter, who is accepting the views without critically thinking through what is being taught. The soldier, who is so angry that he views the world in such madness and cannot reconcile with a father. Bruno and Schmuel: the innocent who just want to be friends and are hurt.  This was well-done and done tastefully. I appreciate that. Thank you.

Here's the deal, if you're going to make a movie about Nazis in Germany and they are all German - give them German accents. Why in the world was EVERYONE in this movie Irish, British or Scottish? 15 minutes in and I keep trying to figure out if there was some back story as to why every single one of them was talking in an Irish, British or Scottish accent? It killed the seriousness of the story and reduced what should have been a great movie.
Also, sad but true - the majority of children too small to work were killed. It's a horrific fact and only shows the brutality of the Nazi regime. So, why was there an English accented boy in the Nazi concentration camp?
Be authentic or don't make the movie at all. You do the story an injustice by making it the Nazi's British, Scottish and Irish. It's an insult to the senses.

My wife being Filipino didn't know a whole lot of what happened during WWII.  It's good that films like these are continuing to be made so we never forget the evil that men do.  This is a good family movie to help teach kids as well as adults who don't want to see the gorier side of things that took place.  Those looks for battle scenes or war footage won't find that here.

Based off of debunked info - The story of the two boys is a farse and was proven to be one in the late 90s. Apparently based on a novel by author John Boyne, the story itself is based off of an elderly jewish couple that used this "tale" to get publicity and money. Investigate yourselves to find out more. I found it difficult to watch knowing that the "basis" of this story was completely made up. The man who plays the little boy later came out apologizing for lying to the media and people for the publicity. His wife only went along because she loved him so much apparently... Once they were caught lying about it because the story didn't add up, she wouldn't make any more appearances with him. Not to mention that all of the "Death Camps" were discovered by the USSR. Never once by English, American, or Allied Forces. Learn some history for yourselves and investigate the truth!
Well done but an unexpected ending

The story is one of innocence and tragedy.  Two young boys, one in the concentration camp, and the other the son of a German commandant who is in charge of the concentration camp strike up an unlikely friendship.  Both boys are unaware of their particular realities and the dire nature of what their friendship will bring.  The story kept me awake for a night pondering the evil that human beings inflict on one another because of ignorance and prejudice.

I have to agree that it has a very sad ending and it's mind bothering.  However, it depicts very strongly one of the darkest chapters in human history.  This will serve as a warning that we should do whatever we can to prevent such a horrible crime from happening again.

A bleeped-up, feel-good FAIRY TALE that sentimentalizes the Holocaust by diminishing the Nazis' chilling efficiency.  Look at that freaking poster for the film.
Then think about how close any concentration camp prisoner EVER got to a fence without being IMMEDIATELY shot dead, unless she or he successfully escaped?
Look at our li'l prisoner's plump, SMILING face. Then check some actual footage of the deathly emaciated real prisoners.  Yeah, some quality time with a Gentile should put a smile right back on your face!  Who needs food?  Who needs parents?
THEN if you want to let inconvenient reality intrude on your rose-colored cry-fest fairy tale, check some STATS about how many children this age were NOT immediately murdered because they weren't "useful."
A despicable, immoral film.  Watching it is an act of immorality.

Haunting. Transporting. Devastatingly necessary. I heard the director Mike Nichols say, the following about another movie (Whose Afraid of Virginia Wolf), "This isn't life. This is ABOUT life." That's what a true and moving fiction is. It's more than life. It's about more than life. It's not meant to depict "reality." This film is meant to illuminate so much more about all of us, as humans. You can't stand on one side of the fence or the other, stand at an emotional distance, and watch this film. Or, rather, you can if you tick off your list of "this would never happen, that would never happen, etc." I've watched this film three times over the years. I always have to steel my self. I'm always devastated and somehow renewed. Illumination does that to a person. I couldn't go away from this film, not once in three viewings, without looking inward at myself and outward at the world entire that allowed the Holocaust to happen and claimed to be "innocent" of all knowledge of it's existence. History continues to repeat itself all over the planet. This film depicts the devolution and destruction of innocence--as metaphor, as historical "fact" re-imagined, as mythology, as story told by a master director, and screen writer who captured the heart of the original novel. Bravo! Bravo! Bravo! This film gives me hope for humanity. Humane humans created this film. The actors, children and adults, portray our beauty, our cruelty, and our devastating innocence.

What a powerful movie.  It shows that German families were also destroyed by the Holocaust.  How psychologically impossible to be aligned with the Final Solution. We needed to see how it affected the dad and the sister, who had fallen into the Nazis' thinking so easily.  Interesting that half of that family fell into it, and half didn't.  What a horrible page in history. Beautiful movie.  The 2 young boys were outstanding.

A lovely and fully-developed film to accompany the book.  Very well casted with talented young actors and wonderful performances by David Thewlis and adult cast.

Is the story devastating?  Yes.  In this case, considering the mission and necessary seriousness of the book, that is very good.  There are various changes from the book's story line but they add to the possibilities of the scenario, rather than damaging it.  Read the book first and then add this to the experience.

Young adult viewers who encounter the film seem to be stunned and appropriately overcome by the end of this film, even after reading the novel and knowing a great deal of what would happen ahead of time.  That will probably and most likely include adult viewers as well.

Interesting story, beautifully shot with a heartbreaking ending.  Two boys, innocent in every respect, separated by war and politics have no idea how the ravages of war play out in their lives.  But they forge an unlikely friendship despite all the unknowns around them.  Both pay a heavy price for being at the wrong place at the wrong time. I've watched this movie several times and it never tires.

Did anyone notice the following verbatim exchange when the boy asked his sister what their father worked?

- Dad's not horrible, is he?
- He's a good man.
- Of course, he is.  But he's in charge of a horrible place.
- It's only horrible for them, Bruno.  We should be proud of Dad, now more than ever before.  HE'S MAKING THE COUNTRY GREAT AGAIN [emphasis added].

Rather ironic, no?

This was a very well-acted, haunting movie about two little boys during the Holocaust. My middle school students read the novel as a way to introduce them to the Holocaust. The plot of the novel, as well as the movie, has been criticized as being unrealistic as to the true horrors of the time period; however, the author refers to the book as a "fable" -- it is not historical fiction. My students questioned how this could have happened -- how so many people could be led to follow such evil. Even though there is no profanity and most of the violence is implied, the movie is still extremely intense. Parents should view the movie prior to allowing their children to watch it.

WOW, this film will impress viewers, because it is filled with emotionally charged scenes taken place during 2nd world war in Germany...a story of a German family who had to move to different location near by the Nazi's work camp used to enslaved and brutally mistreated the Jews and worse, yet. This movie told a story of how a young 8 years old German filled with curiosity to explore the so called the "farm" and befriended a 8 years old Jewish boy prisoner. After some secret meetings with the Jewish boy with out the knowledge of German boy's parents of his whereabouts during his absence. In progress of time as shown in the film that German boy began to question about his father's job as Nazi official and understanding the difference of good and evil. The music played in the movie was very sad. The ending of the film will shock you of what had happened! Very moving and so unexpected!

Innocent, compassionate, evocative.  Other reviewers complain about the ending.  ***Spoiler*** I guess they would rather one boy die alone and apart from his friend?  The beauty in this is you're aware of the crematory half-way through the film, but you're probably not as emotionally engaged at that point.  This speaks to our human nature.  We can be aware of a great evil, but so long as we're not directly connected to affected by it it may not move us to feel much.  When something or someone connects us, as does our young protagonist here, it suddenly becomes heart wrentching and an awful spectacle.  ***End Spoiler***

While at times this movie might seem to be a bit slow or simple, it's beautifully presented because it's almost entirely from the perspective of the small German boy. He doesn't know about all the war stuff going on, he's been kept relatively isolated from all of it by his father and mother, and when he is exposed to some of the horrors of the war and of how the Jewish people are being treated and murdered, it is presented by his father and sister as acceptable and normal. A Jewish man that he knows personally can be beaten to death and he accepts it with only a passing amount of fear and upset. This is how his world works, which is horrifying to contemplate.
In the end, I have seen many reviewers who say things like "The father will now realize he's been wrong... " and such but I feel that in real life, the father would simply have blamed the Jews for everything, instead of seeing his victims in a different light, relating to his own tragedy. I did not feel any hope for the father's soul at all.
In the end, it is one of the more powerful movies presented in a slightly unusual way and it's entirely successful in doing it and affecting the viewers emotionally and mentally. While sad and upsetting, it brings the Holocaust into your living room and makes it personal, forcing you to remember that each and every murdered victim of the Nazis was someone's child, someone's father or mother... and that is always a good thing. If we forget, it could happen all over again and the world does not need that lesson again.

My high school English Language Learners gained insight into the horrific episode of history by watching this film today.  I appreciate that it demonstrates the spread of Nazi propaganda during the Third Reich without graphic images of the Holocaust. Outstanding movie in spite of the difficult subject matter.  If I were teaching a course in "film" at the college level this would be the number one1 film to explore.  The symbolism, foreshadowing, and imagery are well worth exploring.  The filmmakers showcase the rise and fall of WWII from the Nazi perspective through the characters.  Their movements, dress, and facial expressions tell the tale of a confident Nazi Germany on the rise to a broken and desperate sociopathic group scrambling to finish their horrifying "final solution" with the Allies breathing down their neck.  In this film, two young boys, victims of a society spun out of control naturally navigate their own worlds coming together without prejudice in an attempt to salvage a fractured childhood.  Their instincts and inner conflict are well documented by the filmmakers who explore the confusing world in which they live.  In the end, boys will be boys and in the world created for them by an evil society, they find a way to do exactly what kids do; play, explore, and pretend.  Their playful exploration has consequences for them and the architects of the final solution.  If ever there was a case of "instant karma," it plays out in this film.

Have you ever seen a person auditioning for some singing show on tv and they weren't bad? Like they did an ok job but there wasn't anything remarkable about them? The Boy in Striped Pajamas is like that. It hits all the usual notes that World War 2 movies hit, and doesnt have anything really special going for it up until the very end. This was a movie that I was looking forward to watching, and just 10 minutes into it, I felt something was wrong. Halfway through, I started thinking up better World War 2 movie ideas, like one where I have Anne Frank being played by Serena Williams, and when the Nazis come in to take her family away, she takes out a few of them with some reverse kicks and elbows, then does a handstand and grabs the lead SS officers head with her legs, throwing him out the window and saving the day. I thought of a lot more and ended up entertaining myself from beginning to end here because this is such an average movie that I was predicting everything that was going to happen for the most part, and was right 3/4 of the time.

Bruno is an 8 year old German boy who moves with his family into a new home after his father is promoted to a higher position in the military. He notices a strange looking farm from his window, noting that all the people wear pajamas while working, and that there are some kids working there too. His mom tries to make him forget about it, but Bruno is curious and makes his way for the farm one day while exploring. There, he meets Shmuel, a Jewish boy behind the electric fence as he performs his duties at the concentration camp. Bruno doesnt know what to make of all of this, and starts to ask Shmuel questions about what hes doing, and assumes that the young boy can leave to come over to his home like any other kid would be able to. Days go by and the two bond a little bit (stress on the little) as Bruno brings the boy food and even toys. Meanwhile, Brunos dad and sister have been brainwashed by the Nazi propaganda, and nothing but their country matters to them, while his mom is stuck holding in her emotions, for fear of being reported a traitor for criticizing anything regarding the Master Plan.

The whole movie is very basic, and for the most part, uninteresting. You have the innocent young boys who don't understand the situation they're in (on either side), a one-dimensional super Nazi father who never shows emotion for anyone or any situation unless it involves his work, the mom who never actually does anything, and the slightly older sister who follows her dads ways, mainly because she develops a crush on one of the soldiers at their house. Bruno is just a young boy, but legitimately has no interest in the war. He wants to be an explorer, and even when his tutor comes by and makes him read a new kind of book, the boy sticks to his guns. He manages to stay pretty normal through the whole movie, never gaining any insight to the war, or having any character development EXCEPT this weird part where he completely cowers down and lies about someone important to him. There are servants in the familys home that are Jewish, and were supposed to feel for them, but they don't get much screen time to do anything other than serve and get yelled at by others. And thats my main problem with the movie- none of the characters are given enough time for me to get attached to, no matter how bad their situation is. Of course I feel bad for Shmuel, but even Brunos sister gets more screen time than he does. You feel bad for him by default, and rarely because you see anything happening to him.

There were other things I didn't like, such as the Nazis being so lenient. When one of the servants is caught eating food from the dinner table, despite it being offered to them, he just gets a verbal slap on the wrist and is told theyll talk more about it later. It turns out that the prisoner didn't really get much of a punishment, all things considered. This same Nazi that yells at the prisoner is yet another character that doesnt have much going for them, and what does come up, is so vague that they may as well have not even included the scene at all. I will say that the ending came out of nowhere, and you're better off just watching the last 25-30 minutes of the movie. It feels like, if the movie is accurate to the book, the author wrote the ending first, then had to piece together the events that lead up to it because its such a shocker. At the same time, by that point, the movie lost me and I didn't feel as bad as I probably should have, or would have, if it were a better movie. Ill give them points for being one of the few WW2 movies Ive seen to show a little more than others Ive seen, and thats all ill say about it.

The Boy in the Striped Pajamas feels like it was made for high school classrooms to watch instead of something better for the Holocaust. The only people I can imagine caring much for this are people who are easily attached to characters based on whats happening to them and not who they are, or anyone thats never seen a World War 2 movie before. Watching it is a lot like doing one of those paint by the numbers pictures, with a repetitive soundtrack thats seemingly comprised of 5 tracks. In the end, this isn't a horrible movie by any stretch of the definition, just very lackluster.

This film is narratively nonsensical (if it were that easy to cross the fence...), historically implausible (a child that age would not be considered suitable by the SS for camp labor and likely would have been gassed immediately), and a gross trivialization of a heretofore unprecedented crime which tries to pull sympathy for both sides of the fence (one side of which was largely responsible for said crime). Setting aside even the basic ethical question of the Holocaust's cinematic representation to begin with, this film is arguably the worst offenders I've ever seen which goes so far as to show the inside of an gas chamber in full effect sans any of the blood, vomit, feces or screams that resulted within 20 horrible minutes of entering it.

I trust that those responsible for this story and film were well-intentioned, but the film remains no less deplorable for going about a subject of this magnitude without the necessary detail, gravity, or perspective necessary in understanding the events that happened in the systematic extermination of the European Jews. If you want to give children an appropriate glimpse, stick with Anne Frank.

As a former military officer in the U.S. Armed Forces, it was my privilege to be involved with studies in Air Command and Staff College (ACSC) and the Air War College.  In addition I received premiere education about the Nuremberg Code of 1947 and the Nuremberg Trials as conducted by Allies as the International War Crimes Trials.  That background is not meant to impress the reader of this review.  Rather I have looked for films that are based on historical novels and take a complicated subject so that the person with an average high school education can be enlightened.  This is accomplished in the DVD, "The Boy In Stripped Pajamas."  Two young actors, Asa Butterfield as Bruno, and Jack Scanlon as Schmuel are magnificent to the point of Genius, who portrayed what could have happened - and did happen - in Work Camps that were in an annex network with a main concentration camp.  The producers in conjunction with Hungarian, British, German and Budapest expertise recreated the tragic atmosphere
of what happened to individuals both directly and indirectly involved with Hitler's final solution.  The Genius of this DVD, is any member of a family
- no matter how young or old - can grasp what happened in the Holocaust - and must not take place again.  I purchased this DVD and it is an essential part of my DVD collection. It is often overlooked that the innocent were exterminated in the WW II camps whether a work place or concentration center.  It is important the young as well as the adults in the world comprehend what the Holocaust was.  Here is an excellent movie
to help gain that understanding in contemporary terms.  Mankind did not cross over into Jordan during the 20th Century - and neither have we in the
21st Century.  This DVD is an superb example to view and learn.

I would recommend instead that you read the Zion Chronicles by Bodie Thoene. These fictional books capture the pain and sufferings of the Jewish people during WWII.  They also tell the story of how the world did not help those that escaped....ships of refuges were turned away from ports in other countries.
John Wayne's comment about Bodie Thoene, "She has that rare kind of talent that captures the people and the times!"

I have been reading and studying WWII and the Holocaust so this movie caught my eye; however, I was sadly disappointed. There were too many inaccuracies and odd activities by characters like why was the mother always going into town? Did she have a job? I found it hard to believe the mother was so naive about her husbands job and what went on in concentration camps. She did tell her kids to stay away from the place but pretends she doesn't know anything. Then after the funeral of her mother-in-law she abandons all senses and takes to drinking heavily.

Hard to believe the 'Boy in the Striped Pajamas' had enough free time to befriend anyone outside the camp. My understanding of the Concentration camps is that inmates, even children, were watched quite closely. There were guard towers and electrified fences.  The scenes  when the Boy was 'looking for his father' seemed unreal. Men were typically sent to all-male camps, whereas children were sent to camps with there mothers.

I tried to convince myself that the ending really could have happened but it was too unrealistic.

I thought it was a story that could have happened; in any case, it was thought-provoking at least. It plays out all sides of emotions of people who were there who ignored what was going on either by choice or by naivet or tender age, or as we all saw it (through of us in America) that the non-Jewish Germans were all hard core sadists committing acts of atrocity as though they loved it and had inherent evil, or were afraid of reprisals and followed it anyway. We all ask ourselves what would we have done? Would we do whatever it took on either side to survive? Would we have committed atrocities to survive? What would we have done? How far would we go? From both sides of the coin? We would like to believe we would have helped the Jews and brave the German reprisals despite the consequences. In France would we have been part of the resistance? Would we have moved to a neutral country? I would like to believe we would do something courageous. We could look at Afghanistan and the continued practice of genocide for years and the Taliban's continued terrorism and how much have we helped? I know my son has been there & in Iraq in the Marines, and I still can't say if we are helping enough. Or we could ask ourselves why this has gone on and on. What is the saying about 'all it takes for evil to grow is that good men do nothing'? I know that is not the quote but something like that. Hugely sad ending, but if were true, I bet the father would take a second look at his actions and observation of atrocities going on around him with a less that blind eye from that point on......................

I borrowed this movie, and the book by the same title, from the library, and I knew I wanted to own both of them. I liked that two young boys became good friends; particularly two young boys who, by virtue of their respective ancestries, were not only supposed to NOT be friends, but were supposed to hate each other. Bruno wasn't very attentive during his lessons from the Herr Liszt, and that, coupled with his only being eight years old, resulted in his retaining a certain degree of innocence, and in making (according to the book) a best friend for life. Bruno and his dad are polar opposites with regard to their personalities. Bruno's dad is a sadist toward the Jews, as evidenced in at least two movie scenes; whereas Bruno is compassionate and sensitive toward his friend, Shmuel, and also toward an older man by the name of Pavel, who also helps him at one point.

Very few stories have angered me as much as this one; though the anger I feel is more along the lines of righteous indignation over what was done to the Jewish people. I'm part German, though, for a time after watching this movie, and reading the book, I was disgusted to have any German ancestry. However, it would be wrong for me to continue to have that attitude; because not every German citizen agrees with what the Nazis did; just like not every Muslim agrees with what the terrorists did; and neither does every citizen of Japan agree with the bombing of Pearl Harbor.

Wow, the ending will make you cry for this kid. Takes place from what can be assumed is at one of the most dastardly concentration camps of WW2. The son of the concentration camps commandant befriends a Jewish intern and it develops into quit a friendship. His parents never know what the child is doing until the very end of the movie when the mother wants no more of her husbands life and wants to take the kids back to Berlin. The young boy tells the Jewish boy to bring him some of what he thinks are the Striped Pajamas and tells him that he will help him find his father. Not knowing what is inside the wire or that the Jewish boys family has already been put to death, he enters the camp with the other boy and soon finds himself being led to the gas cambers. What follows will make you cry for not only what happens to the Jewish race but also the commandants son.

This is NOT a movie for young children!!!! If you have an older child who would like to learn about the Holocaust, then, by all means show it to him/her. This is a view of the Holocaust through the mind of a child. Though it's really about 2 children - the second boy's view is limited Neither boy really understand what's going on. That is the beauty of this movie. The main character is a young boy from a wealthy family. He does not understand that his father is in charge of a concentration camp. We learn all about his family and what happens when people disagree with them. (Note: The sudden elimination of the grandmother.) Young children do not understand prejudice. That is a central theme here. The young boy in the camp also feels the same way. The complete innocence of the young boys is what makes this film so remarkable. Children cannot control or change an adult's world. No matter how much they want to.

This movie speaks volumes about societal biases against those who are merely different from us.  You could apply this same scenario and replace the Germans then hatred for the Jews with any other, whether it be race, religion, political party, sexual orientation, or just about any other reason we can conjure up to hate each other.

The innocence of children who haven't yet been taught to hate, or even see that someone else is "different" is refreshing.  The ending of the movie is horrendous, yet somehow I took the slightest bit of satisfaction from the gravity of the situation towards the perpetrators.

The premise reminds me of the words from a song in South Pacific:  "You've got to be taught before it's too late, before you are six, or seven, or eight, to hate all the people your relatives hate, you've got to be carefully taught".

There are so many incredible true stories from the Holocaust, making this fictional one filled with inaccuracies too hard for me to swallow. It is unfathomable that a child of Bruno's age who was the son of a high-ranking Nazi officer did not know about Jews; he would have been precisely the target of Nazi anti-Semitic propaganda, which would have surrounded him for his entire life. Furthermore, his mother's portrait as an innocent who had no idea of what was going on in the concentration camp where they lived is completely unbelievable. Nazi women were typically co-perpetrators of Holocaust crimes, and she most certainly would have shared in her husband's hatred of Jews.

If you are looking for a film about the Holocaust that has historical integrity, watch "The Piano", "Schindler's List", or "Life is Beautiful". Or, better yet, watch any of the fantastic documentaries available - truth is much more important than fiction when it comes to this important topic.

This movie takes you inside the household of a high ranking SS officer, who has moved his family into a house near a concentration camp.  The officer's little boy is intrigued by what he thinks is some kind of farm nearby, and he goes there to see it.  He meets a little Jewish boy his own age, and thru the fence they become friends.  The officer's son doesn't really know what they do in the camp, and he keeps returning to see the little boy and play checkers or whatever they can.  The movie shows how the wife of the officer reacts when she realizes what the camp is, and how the teenaged daughter reacts.  The officer follows his orders.  Until one day their little boy can't be found, and they realize he has gone to the camp.  They all race there, trying to find him.  He thought it great fun to put on a pair of 'striped pajamas' like his friend wears, and he gets swallowed up in a crowd of Jews being hurried into a big building ...

This is a different perspective of the Jewish Holocaust of WWII from the eyes of the innocent 8 year son of a Nazi concentration camp commandant. I challenge anyone who watches this to closely examine their initial thoughts and feelings at the end.

This is one of the most thought provoking movies I have watched. It stands out from other movies from this time period because the story is told through the eyes of a child. Other reviewers here have said that this is not historically accurate and some have said that it should not be shown in the classroom because of this. I would encourage you to look past the historical inaccuracies and realize that the movie and the book are showing the psychological and emotional atrocities that human nature can produce. For teachers reluctant to show this in a classroom because of it's historical inaccuracies, I would explain it just as I have here before showing the film.
It is correct that families of soldiers did not live next to concentration camps. However, they are there to help tell the story in the innocent eyes of a child. It is a literary technique that works very well here and I believe the story was well written and the actors did an amazing job.

If you want more intellectual understanding of the culture of fear, propaganda ,misdirection, fanaticism and acceptance of terrorizing acts beneath a slimed veneer of success in this period of history of Nazi Germany, I'm sure there are many venues, but this little story has everything in it if you are alert and observant.
  I was charmed by the title; "pajamas" as comforting euphemism for the horror of dehumanizing camps; the meeting of two young  boys in the midst of chaos gives it a sheen of redemption; and the synopsis " whose friendship has unintended consequences.." a big breath of hope.  I don't usually write reviews unless very moved, especially if others have well written analyses and shared their feelings.  In this case, the brief reviews still made it seem mild, to me.
  But I must warn you, despite the protagonist being an 8 year old boy,this is in no way for children.  Perhaps  if your family is interested and informed about the rise of Naziism in a very despondent German economy, and how Hitler carefully picked innocent "enemies of the state" and how people  managed to avoid information about the exterminations, then it could be understood.  It is extremely well acted; beautifully filmed, and written so that it seems  every viewpoint and awareness level is represented. The timeframe of the story in film format seems condensed at the finality; but it really shapes nicely.
  It opens with the German officer father of the family being promoted as supervisor of a countryside Crematorium, although this information is carefully withheld.  There is a very revealing frisson between this officer and his mother at the celebratory party.
His father and he, however, seem of a similar emotional mold.  The family must move from  a beautiful home in beautiful and culturally appealing Berlin to miles away in the country into a house that really yells of the inhumanity and precise coldness of the job the father  must supervise and improve.  The pre-adolescent daughter copes by putting away her dolls, embracing the party line, developing a crush,and moving toward becoming a Hitler Youth; the 8 year old boy, at first bored, follows his natural bent, and begins exploring, eventually finding his way to the "farm" - the camp (and crematorium), where he meets "Schmuel" another 8 year old boy. who, in many of his actions and observations seems more mature and brave than he.
  Their interactions, which must stay hidden from mum and dad, are so heartfully innocent, you feel a big breath of air.  In a moment of fear, the German boy brings harm to Schmuel, and feeling ashamed, wants to help make up for it.  The end of the story is nigh; he conceives of a way to help Schmuel, by getting IN to the camp to help find the latter's father who has disappeared.  The ruse of
another pair of "pajamas" makes a costume, and they are successfully seeking, when the warning horn goes off, rounding everyone up.  They are told they must undress and will be cleaned and showered.  By now, the mother, frantic to find her son, has interrupted
"an important meeting" to get the father's help.  You are on the edge of your chair, tapping your foot; wondering can they, will they, make it in time?

Despite the father's ascendency, expertise and quick action, the very efficient actions he programmed have gone into action.  No, they can not make it in  time.

You are left with such an overwhelming sense of pathos for every single character, because violence harms the perpetrator as much as the victim, though in different ways.  I wondered, if I  were this boy's mother, what would I do?  Would it change me if I were the father; would I become harder, more angry, or perhaps commit suicide?  And  with what unbearable confusion must the daughter deal ?  The story ended when it should have ended, but it didn't end inside me.
Excellent movie with an ending I did not expect.  The acting was also very good just wish the movie was a little longer at the end to explain what happens to the other characters.

A celebration of misery, and of the destruction of innocent children. There is nothing redeeming about this movie. It is neither based on a specific true account, nor is it a worthwhile story to be told. It is merely a story of a fictional child living near a Nazi concentration camp who befriends a Jewish boy, with predictably tragic results. If you like fictional tragic stories based loosely on historical events, this film will likely bring you the emptiness you seek. Otherwise stay away from this one- you'll be glad you did.

I'm still thinking about this movie days after I watched it. After his father, an SS officer, is reassigned, the family settles into the new house but Bruno struggles to adjust to having no friends, a tutor who "brings schools to them" and the "strange farm workers" he can see through the woods. Against his mother's wishes he sneaks out of the front yard (where he cannot catch glimpses of the concentration camp) and eventually finds a "friend" he can only talk through through the fence. He visits most days, bringing food with him, but since he's only 8, Bruno struggles to understand what the camp really is and why Shmuel doesn't want to play catch or anything, becoming more confused when he sees a film (propaganda) about such camps. Meanwhile, his older sister quickly embraces the new ideas their tutor and some of their fathers soldiers promote as their mother grows increasingly suspicious of what exactly is happening at the camp and wants to take the children away. The story is gripping with the different "levels" of knowing -- from the father who is an officer to the mother who doesn't want to see to Bruno who questions it all as he tries to understand how his friend can be "the enemy." More importantly the choices the adults have made, accepting, pretending to accept, or remaining in denial, play out toward a gripping final scene when a child finds the strength to keep a vow to his friend. Haunting, beautiful, and heart-wrenching all at once. Highly recommend.

This movie is an example of why I think there is actually a useful and helpful purpose for film. Where most films seek to entertain by appealing to the tastes of a selfish, immoral culture, this film takes us into a world that we wish would not have happened, but it did, and causes us to think about the preciousness of life, and the horror of war. It speaks so powerfully to the dangers of blind believism, and how the masses can be duped by the ideology of violent people. This is a wonderful, though painful movie.

The Boy In The Striped Pajamas juxtaposed the value of lives based solely on the race of a particular culture. In the end the family that held these stringent beliefs of superiority had to confront how this mindset directly impacted their lives.

Since I play an active role as a volunteer with a homeless shelter - I have come to realize that some of the most intelligent individuals can fall to their knees in spite of the fact that they look down on another race.

My personal takeaway in watching this movie is to look at beliefs and choices through the eyes of a child.

With this view in mind, individuals are given the opportunity to lift another human being who has fallen to their knees based upon our commonalities vs. race based ideology which in this movie poignantly devalues the life of another human being.

This film plot has all the elements of greatness. It is a well executed period drama around WWII Nazi Germany, high living in Berlin, and the Jewish Genocide. If you want to get a view of a child's pure Innocent towards the atrocities and the evil of  a world wide contagion of antisemitism, then this film is for you. The ironies at the conclusion of the film are almost overwhelming. It is not for the faint of heart nor for those shadowed in innocence.  It is a reverberating message of the true savagery  of all those who persecute the Jews today in the name of religion or state sponsored terror. One should remember that  many of Hitlers socialist programs had roots in the populist eugenic  progressive movements of  the 30's in the  USA.

This is an Irish-English production of 2007, beautifully filmed in Hungary.  It is the story of an officer in the new Nazi regime in 1940's Berlin and surrounding countryside.  The book of the same name is meant to be a fable so any lack of resemblance to real German history is therefore to be excused.  It has sold over 3 million copies, meant to be a "young adult" book, and is clearly fiction.  Yet its Irish author Boyne has written it convincingly.

Our head officer, recently promoted to a labor camp commandant, has to leave a lovely villa in Berlin and decides to take his wife and family with him.  His newly assigned house is ridiculously close to the camp so the younger son Bruno, age 8, is slipping out the back garden to see what he can see.  He thinks he is an explorer.  He finds what he thinks is a strange farm where the farmers and the children wear striped pajamas.

Little does he realize that it is the labor camp his father runs nor does his quick mind ever seem to grasp that it is evil.  He is the son of a very important man of the party yet does not know what a Jew is, we are led to believe.

He and his older sister are not attending any school but just have an old male tutor come twice a week to teach Nazi history.  Very odd for a family of this standing!  They have no playmates; the older sister's role is that of a preteen falling for a young Nazi assistant officer's charms and the spell of the Nazi movement and BDM for girls.

Nonetheless let us not quibble. Bruno makes friends with a Jewish boy, also 8,named Schmuel, who is hiding behind a pile of lumber at this labor camp.  They begin to talk and know each other.  Neither has ever heard the other's name before and finds the other's name absurd.  Yet Schmuel speaks German and probably had a very German life before 1940.  HE was probably called Samuel or some such equivalent.  Both boys are excellent in their parts, especially Asa Butterfield as the Nazis' son, with his intensity of emotions and big blue eyes.

The Kommandant's wife is outraged when she realizes the extent to which her nation's new regime is intent on eliminating Jews.  She had mentally accepted labor camps, but not death camps, until the stench of the ovens' smoke reached her in her new home.  She makes a strange remark about another boy's mother not having any say about the political affiliation of the family.

For those who have studied Nazi ideology, the women were clearly not considered in any way serious members of the party, only to be married to them and support them with housework and home comforts and so on.  To discuss and know what their government was doing to them, to their children, to their neighbors and friends, to Jews and Gypsies and homosexuals - that was not the province of women.

The boys meet often and things evolve then escalate to tragedy.  For those details, read the book or see the film.

What is a viewer to think of the shocking ending?  I am not sure at all even knowing a lot about those times.  That the death of a German, inadvertantly killed amongst Jews, is more shocking and penetrating to the heart, than the murder of millions?  Some would say that is the basic storyline.

I was not so surprised as others seemed to be at the ending.

It is a fable after all.

I think the power of these WWII stories are diminishing as time moves forward.  So much else has happened in USSR and in China, North Korea,Iran, Cambodia, Vietnam, and now all the Middle Eastern nations in chaos, etc etc.

Other stories of other nations should be told, perhaps even compared, so that "young adults" can learn to analyze.
