Great Movie. Well acted and well written.  Still the premise of the story convinces me that all Germans knew of the atrocities that occurred.  They, as all obedient Germans did what they well told---and what they were told by their leaders was exactly what they wanted to hear:  Others were to blame for all their miseries, not them.  Which made the atrocities easy to accept. After all, they chose their leaders---and how could they even begin to think that they were wrong? In their minds they weren't--as neither were their leaders.  Because Germans believe they are the master race....and superior people can't ever make mistakes or ever be wrong. There is no wrong when it comes to being a master race--just attempts to disprove the already entrenched lie.

This movie is remarkable in the drama it creates around the chilling story of a WW2 concentration camp and the contrast between the life of the son of the prison's commandant and that of the boy in the striped pajamas, who is one of the inmates. The courage of these children to violate the rules while just being boys tugs at your heartstrings, and their innocence in the face of such terror leaves you wondering if it is possible in such circumstances for kids to reach across the fence that separates them and see each other as friends and in that excitement that only children can have be oblivious to what is really going on around them. The casting of the actors is superb. The sets so compelling they make you believe it is real. It is astonishingly well done. This is one of the best period pieces I have ever seen in my life and I think that the reality it brings to the screen allows you to view this topic without being totally repulsed by the content of the disaster. Definitely a must see.

The Boy in the Striped Pajamas was a soul capturing story that touched the heart. The two young boys who could bypass class, nationality, and status formed a friendship of love and acceptance. The wife's disapproval of her husband's cruelty toward the Jews because of his rank in the German gestapo, caused a break in their marriage. The final scene was the teaching point of the movie. I thought it was a movie that had many moral lessons that could well be applied to our own circumstances no matter where we live.

Very well executed. I shake my head at some of the ditzy reviews that complain about the actors speaking with British accents. It's a British film, duh. Would you prefer dialogue in German, with subtitles? And some of the complainers have read the book - in English - and still complain. That's just incomprehensible.

Anyway, I came to this film knowing nothing about the book, nor the plot. That's certainly the best way to approach it, and I will offer no spoilers to ruin that. I wavered between four and five stars, but went with five because of the skillfully paced power of the last part of the film. It was memorable.

This....I'll say family but really the father's Only regret in his involvement in all of this....was his son just happened to break in on the wrong day at the wrong time.  Thats it.  Has no regrets for what he is actually doing and no I don't think his son being killed will change his mind on the matter if nothing else would likely make him worst.  I cant seem him quitting, or changing only blaming it all on the Jew who "tricked" him into the camp.

I do not think this film does the book any justice. It would have been nice of they actually went to a concentration camp and made their film more like actual events. The size of the camp in the field seems very small compared to what they were. And what happened to blonde hair and blue eyes? The history and true facts of the world war during the rise of Hitler are not correctly represented in this movie.

I would say this movie is a spin off of some very small factual data than an accurate representation of the book. I was highly disappointed and wanted to stop watching it after 15 minutes but promised myself to finish it to the end. If you are looking for an accurate or even close to accurate rendition, this is not the movie. If you are vaguely familiar with true historical events, you will be disappointed by this film.

The pros of this film would be the way that the (Spoiler) population was not correctly informed of current events.

Where to begin

A good friend had been on me to watch this movie for some time.  I resisted, probably because of the title of the movie: it didn't sound all that interesting.  But, after a recent visit with him. where we tried to view the movie on Netflix but had an audio problem, I ordered the DVD.  As soon as it arrived, I popped it into my Blu-ray player.  I won't divulge anything about the plot, other than to say the movie is set in World War II German occupied lands, touches on one of the darkest times in human history, and concerns an unlikely friendship between two young boys.

All the actors speak with a British accent, which might seem a bit odd, since it's not what a person might expect from these characters.  But it was a very minor distraction, since the story grabbed me right from the start.  The acting is top-notch and the quality of the DVD was excellent. 'The Boy in the Striped Pajamas' proves you don't need special effects to make an amazing movie. I always enjoy viewing a 'Making Of' special feature, to gain insight into the creation of the movie, and was happy one was included with this DVD.  All of the major players contributed to it.

I don't know this movie's rating, but I truly believe that it ought to be required viewing for every Middle or High School student before they are allowed to graduate.  History had a tendency to repeat itself, if we don't stop it.
Very informative .

The Boy in The Striped Pajamas is one of those movies that sticks with you, and can bring tears even when you are not watching it. The movie, even though it is fiction, says more about the pain of the "final solution", the ability to look beyond differences, and the power of love that can reach audiences from ten to one-hundred. I wish everyone would watch it with open hearts. I have watched it four times, and I know it will never leave my film library. The directors, producers, actors, writers, and anyone involved in creating this masterpiece did a remarkable job of delivering the story of our inability to understand the consequences of hate and bigotry until it takes one we love.

It's hard to find videos that are appropriate for students in teaching history. This is a VERY good find.

I chose this film because it was recommended to me.  A very good movie, it shows the complete innocence of a child.  Regardless of what adults/parents think or believe most times the kids turn out to be the innocent victims.  The German boy became fast friends with the Jewish boy and died without realizing what decision he made was fatal.  Very interesting would recommend it to the youths so they can realize the value of friendship and to appreciate others.

This film shows the war from the perspective of a child.  The innocence is a teaching moment for adults who prejudice a group of people, blindlessly.  Interesting how much the older sister was more open to this sentiment without questioning like her younger sibling.  And there was a bittersweet justice at the end for the father and his crimes.  The worst kind.

I would highly recommend this movie for those who like a wonderful, touching story about this time.  Another similar film is "Lore" which looks at the children of German officers of the Third Reich.

"The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is atypical of a holocaust film in that it is told primarily through the eyes of Bruno, the eight-year-old son of a German soldier. When we first meet Bruno and his family, they are living a seemingly happy life in Berlin. However, when Bruno's father receives a promotion, they move to a farm in the countryside, next to what we soon discover is a concentration camp. His father has been chosen as commandant of that camp.

Unlike in Berlin, where Bruno had multiple playmates and was free to run around with them, in the country he is alone (except for his family) and confined to their yard. However, a born adventurer, he finds a way to escape his yard and is soon at the perimeter of the concentration camp, where he meets a youth of his age, a boy who (as Bruno sees it) wears striped pajamas.

The film does an extremely effective job of showing us this segment of the world through the eyes and thought-patterns of an eight-year-old child, a child who wants to believe that his father is a good man, even a hero, but who can't quite square this with what he sees, as he witnesses the "farmers" on the other side of the fence working in their "pajamas," as he watches the smoke from the chimneys inside the camp and smells the putrid odor they give off, and as he learns from his "playmate" about the people in the camp who have mysteriously disappeared.

Even in his home he receives conflicting messages. His father and mother both show love and affection to him; yet, his father and the solider boyfriend of his older sister treat with contempt the Jewish concentration-camp inmate who must work long hours for them while having almost nothing to eat, and who is severely beaten for the smallest infraction.

To the end, Bruno seemingly ignores the obvious, or, perhaps better put, tries to square the discordant data with a positive assessment of the life of the people on the other side of the fence, including the boy in the striped pajamas. Even though Bruno is just eight years old, one might wonder how he could continue to turn a blind eye toward the unmistakable horror of what is going on. In a sense, Bruno becomes a metaphor for the German people of the Nazi era, many of whom ignored as best they could what was happening and reinterpreted the data in a way that permitted them to claim ignorance.

It brought out every emotion in me. Although I figured what the ending would be, I continued to hope it wasn't so, but then again I thought, "Isn't that what the father had been doing to other's children. Then again, is it revenge we really want?? The children here can teach the adults what really matters in life. Innocence is pure.

If one cannot justify actions to a child, the actions are likely unjustifiable.

This review will contain potential spoilers throughout. That's fair warning for anyone who hasn't seen it because this movie is impossible to discuss without referring to the events.

It is my opinion that Viktor Frankl would be displeased. An eminent psychologist who survived three concentration camps, he hypothesized the "meaning-drive" and an existential approach to therapy that would deal with it. He wrote frequently about the human need and capacity to create meaning in any situation, no matter how horrid. Of course he wrote extensively on Holocaust experiences to defend his views.

From that standpoint, I think this movie is a complete failure. What are we ultimately to learn? Frankl himself believed the task of great fiction was to help us interpret the meanings of the unique conditions of each individual. So let us take each individual in the movie.

We have "Kurt," the soldier who's sent to the front lines for not reporting his father, yet he learns nothing in the movie. He's horrid straight up until his disappearance, lest we're to interpret his tousling of Bruno's hair as a transformation. There's Bruno's sister who falls victim to propaganda and has nothing more than minor emotional reactions to any event of the film aside from the ending.

There are Bruno's parents. The father who acts as if he's been completely brainwashed. He has one line about "sometimes you have to do things you don't want to," and there's no evidence he's referring to the atrocities he's committing. Other than that, he's emotionless throughout. We see him as a true fundamentalist authoritarian without a thought in his head or a conscience anywhere in sight. His final look of the film is simply one of surprise, and I'm still not sure he learned anything. The mother is utterly useless. She's caught between not seeming disloyal so that her horror show of a husband won't report her to the authorities, and the eventual revelations she suffers which cause her to snipe at him from across the table. There's no growth here either.

This brings us to the heart of the film: Bruno and Schmuel. They're both innocent. Neither of them ever learns anything about their situation. Bruno at best questions the wisdom of his tutor or the ethics of his father once or twice, but neither of those are pursued as even side-stories. Then they both die.

Ultimately this brings us to the question of what have we gained from this experience? None of the characters have gained anything. If they ever do, it occurs after the movie which doesn't count in terms of the story. Write about the change of the character(s) is storytelling 101. As a viewer, it could be a revenge plot. Does the father deserve the suffering inflicted upon him, and does Bruno deserve to die to enact it? That's awfully fatalistic and cynical though, and Frankl's point was that we can find meaning in any individual experience no matter how horrible. Friendship prevails to the end? Children are naive? There is simply no depth to be applied here.

We don't need to know that the Holocaust was horrible. Anyone who needs to be informed of that won't learn it from this movie. So at the end of the day the film is emotional, jarring, shocking, and any number of the numerous adjectives used to describe it, but it fails as the meaningful interpretation of an individual life. In that sense it lets down both the viewer, and someone who I think is one of the greatest minds to survive the Holocaust.

This film gave insight to the innocents of children, whether Jew or (in the case of this film) Catholic. Clearly, we see that (at first), not all the German citizens were aware of the Nazi plan. The father's intensified hatred toward the Jews moved forward with such chaotic speed, he could never have known its impactful devastation, unless, of course, it was to jackknife into his own family.

As a movie and work of fiction, I think this movie was a good movie if you don't take history into account.  It was a little slow in parts, but overall the movie was engaging.  If I was only judging the movie based on its merit as a movie, I would rate it 4 stars.  However when a story regards a very important part of history, I don't think you can look at them separately.  You have to look at how closely to history the movie comes to representing the era about which it is written.  Sadly this movie is all fiction.

Because of Bruno's naivety as well as Shmuel's, I don't find the story plausible.  I also find it offensive that it could convey the message that it would be easy for a German to form a friendship with a Jew in a concentration camp.  Historically German males were indoctrinated through Hitler Youth at very young ages, and they would not be ignorant on the subject of the Jew especially at Bruno's age.  I'm also pretty sure that Jews knew that death surrounded them and a 8-year-old Jewish boy in a concentration camp would be wise beyond his years.  He would know that his father was gassed or burned.  He would not be able to sneak off by himself to strike up a friendship with a German boy.  Officers would have been overseeing all of the population at the concentration camp, so I don't think anyone would be able to go off by themselves. I would imagine that SS officers patrolled the entire fenceline to ensure it was protected, so Bruno digging under the fenceline would never happen.  There are just too many holes in the story to make it believable.

I think it's a nice try by the author to create an alternate reality so to speak.  A what if ___ happened?  But no matter what fairy tale story you want to make, there is just no way this could have happened.  In some ways it is like the author is desperately trying to make an atrocity have a human element to it.  An innocence that has never been substantiated by history.  No matter how much you want to believe that one human group could never do something this inhumane to another human group, sadly it does happen.  It has happened.  We must learn from history, so history does not repeat itself.  But trying to rewrite history by changing the Nazi mindset to include innocence of the German youth is not only untrue but offensive to the millions of Jews who died by Nazi hands.

my grandmother saw her parents and many others lined up and shot by a Nazi death squad. of course I thought about her the whole time I watched this, she was only a little girl around the same age as Shmuel. I honestly don't think she would be able to stomach watching this film as it would be more traumatic than most of the footage from the Holocaust and other films we have seen. because she lost her childhood and innocence and lived through the war as one so young, I believe this would simply be too much for her. but not for the rest of us. I'd never even heard of this story, the book or the movie. it came up randomly on my list of recommendations and my cat accidentally pressed the play button with his paw as I was about to watch something else (I often find WWII movies completely cliche and poorly portrayed) I'm pretty sure I was *meant* to watch this beautiful movie. ALL of the cast and supporting actors were superb. Vera Farmiga as the mom was just a joy to watch. clearly Bruno was his mother's son while Gretel was her father's daughter, down to their physical characteristics I felt that was made quite clear from the start.

this movie is wonderful on so many levels, aside from the eloquent story it is quite amazing down to the last detail. having grown up in Eastern Europe I can say that I felt quite 'at home' with the chosen location and small details. I was very happy to see the story juxtaposed against every day life of the German family who lived comfortably, ate and dressed well and the like while mere miles away people were undergoing unspeakable horrors. as to the criticism of the boys naivete, I can understand but feel that people are dwelling on this in a manner that shows their own lack of understanding and cynicism. how can an 8 year old possibly comprehend such things? I was younger than that when my family had to sit me down and explain that I was a jew. what they said made absolutely no sense (even though I knew I was different) kids were of course propagandized and taught every form of anti-semitism from a young age, but this varied from place to place, family to family. some kids played together with no real strife or tension until the war escalated. kids were not walking around with iPads and smart phones, tweeting to their friends or playing with their Xbox. those kids were beautifully naive and innocent compared to many of our children who take the stance of a young adult before they understand anything whatsoever.

lastly, everyone who sees this film needs to picture millions of Shmuels (that child actor's face was so painfully honest and real) these were people from every corner of europe, with extended families. think of all the mothers and fathers of all the Shmuels who were tortured and sacrificed...for nothing. think of the Polish, german, hungarian and other citizens going about their daily lives while jews lived in filth, beaten and murdered daily. this movie encapsulates all of that and so much more.

This film was really pretty good, but it has some problems I couldn't get past. The first thing I found only slightly irritating is that it took a bit of time to get used to american and British actors playing Germans who spoke with a British accent. Not a major problem of course but none the less it was a little bit of an annoyance. Secondly, I am having a very hard time believing that such an event could have actually happened. Not knowing if this film is based on a true story or not had me wondering that if it did happen, how? There was some things that didn't make sense. For instance a German boy befriends a Jewish boy by secretly sneaking off from his home near a concentration camp where the Jewish boy was imprisoned. He goes to the site to see what it was really like there out of an adventurous spirit. Anyway the friendship that develops between these two boys happens in broad daylight, through a fence that is in plain view of risen guard shacks around the camp. The two play games like checkers, and the German boy brings food and often passes it through the fence to the Jewish boy. So it's very hard to swallow that no Nazi guard saw any of this at all and attempted to put a stop to it. The story as a whole only works if the situation is believable. But based on the very small concrete pile that was meant to hide the goings on between the two boys, it simply is not plausable that within the visual representation that this friendship could have ever happened. If it did and the story is true then the film fails to make the scenario believable. I also found it difficult to believe that this very intelligent German boy could remain so clueless about this camp and not at least know something very bad was going on in there. Basically though this film tells a much different story than other films about the Holocaust and it was very well acted and well made, and I was happy to see that there was nearly no violence in the entire film.
Hard film to watch however, I recommend this to everyone because it is necessary to see this film. You'll become speechless watching it.
Love this movie - read the book with my 11th graders and although it was from a child's point of view, they loved it!

I'm really SHOCKED right now.  Talk about a moving film.  More like soul-crushingly moving.  You know for years, ever since grade school in fact, I've often wondered if any such communication between the German and Jewish children actually took place in secret.  I think about these kind of things all the time.  Even during important history lessons- when I was supposed to be taking notes for an upcoming test, instead I spent my time daydreaming over scenarios nearly identical to the one portrayed in the Boy In the Striped Pajamas.

The greatest thing about being a child is that, they don't automatically hate what they don't understand.  Instead, children are, more times than not, curious and confused.  When a German kid takes a walk through the forest and finds a concentration camp victim around his age sitting alone and depressed, the two of them immediately hit off a wonderful friendship.  Curiosity gets the best of both children- the German boy doesn't understand why the Jewish boy on the other side of the electric fence can't come out to play, so initially he assumes the boy must be locked inside a playground and thinks he's lucky.  This is exactly what any child his age would think.  At least, I know *I* would have.  Children really do have more sense than adults whether intentional or not, and this movie shows a perfectly fine example.

As a 30-year old man myself, and I honestly don't want to turn this into a debate by any means, I have a difficult time believing grown men would actually think it's right to kill a group of others based on their religion.  I realize I'm too locked into the modern world to even comprehend what really occurred back in the early 40's other than what I've seen in movies and read in history books, but... grown men (German soldiers) that believe killing other human beings is actually right, and to not even give it a second thought?  I don't get it at all.

I will NOT spoil the ending and I really hope nobody else does either.  I don't even want to say whether it's a happy or sad ending.  Let's just say, it's totally shocking.  However, you can probably guess judging by the melodic and downbeat soundtrack that tends to focus around light orchestration and piano.

The one thing that confused me and perhaps I missed a crucial storyline element somewhere along the way (I admit, I often have a hard time focusing on the fine details) is why the entire German family has a British accent.  I imagine the British wouldn't care for this at all (especially the elderly) since it might paint a false view of the events that really happened during World War II.  In other words, the British accents might lead the more uninformed movie watchers out there to believe it was the British responsible for the war.  They should have focused the movie on actual Germans and their accents so there's no misunderstandings whatsoever.

Overall, a war movie focusing on a child's viewpoint.  Expect more emotions and less fighting.  That makes the Boy in the Striped Pajamas highly recommendable.

This has to be one of the best movies I've ever seen in my life. Based on the moving and dramatic novel by John Boyne (most recommended you'll read the book first, equally excellent, before you get to the movie), this is the extraordinary tale of a small German eight-year old kid named Bruno, a kid full of curiosity and motivation that happens to live during one of the most horrible periods of time - that of the Second War World. One fateful day, Bruno moves to live with his family to a far away place, at least far away from his beloved Berlin, where he's leaving behind him his close friends and his former lifestyle. Now, desolated from any urban place known to Bruno, his new house is located near what he's mistaken to assume is a farm, a farm filled with strange inhabitants, all dressed in some kind of striped black and white pajamas, and all with a gloomy and rather sad look in their eyes. Bored with his new house which seem to be isolated from the real world, and having no new friends that he can visit nearby, Bruno decides to explore the vast 'farm' territory he can see in the distance from his bedroom window. One day, during one of his wanderings near the huge peculiar fence that separates his world from 'the other world' he sees a small boy, his age, sitting on the ground on the other side of the fence. This boy, Bruno guesses, is one of those 'farmers' dressed in the striped pajamas. From this point on in the story the two kids develop a most unusual and deep friendship, whose tragic consequences will be revealed just towards the end of the story.
The things here are more complicated than what they seem, considering the fact Bruno's father is no less than the threatening commander of the 'farm' - which is actually a death camp, one of those who sealed the miserable fate of the Jews victims during that horrible war... Bruno represents the childhood innocence still not destroyed, while his father - which Bruno adores, by the way - represents cruelty and terror, although of-course between the four walls of his home he's a most loyal, kind and loving husband and father to his two children, a girl and a boy. While Bruno's sister, Gretel, becomes a fan of the Nazis ideas, Bruno is not aware of the horrifying events that occur outside his world - and so, he brings some hope, ray of sunshine and laughter to the short life of poor Shmuel, who's one and only 'sin' is being born a Jew. For almost a year Bruno keeps on meeting with his new friend, until one day they both disappear... Leaving us only to imagine what were their last thoughts during their last minutes among the living.
This is one film that seems too tragic to be true, but as they say, the truth is sometimes crueler than imagination, and it's terrible to think this story could really happen in reality... What I liked especially here is the fact you get to hear the story of the Jewish biggest tragedy of all times from the perspective of an Ari boy, and that serves as a reminder to us that not all the people related to Nazis where vicious or  cruel; Sometimes they just happen to be relatives of the monsters called Nazis by chance, not really on their own will. As a proof to that, I found the scenes in which Bruno's mother fights with her husband about his controversial decision of moving to live near a death camp, really reliable and emotional, as I'm sure a lot of wives of these devils didn't reconcile with the fact their husbands are heartless murderers who are able of doing all the horrors in the world once they get an order. In my opinion, this movie gives you the lesson of what might happen when the two worlds - of healthy childhood and the other, of pure insanity and blood-spilling - are colliding. Indeed, more tragic results than what's happening here you won't get to find anywhere else.
I was more than impressed with the crew of wonderful actors, each one devoted to his/her role in the most convincing way. You'll be amazed at how people who lived among us not even one-hundred years ago yet, could lack humanity and compassion, like the Nazis were. A tearjerker all the way and extremely moving, this is a film not to be missed, always to remember and not forget. Grab a hold of it as fast as you can, and share the unbelievable love and harmony between two little boys, not so surprisingly very much alike despite the huge gap supposed to exist between them. Which goes to show the spirit can win all situations.

This is a film adaptation of a book of the same name by John Boyne.  Although completely fictional and highly improbable, the movie has a visceral punch that will literally knock the wind out of you.  Briefly, the movie is about a German family in which the father become the commandant of a Jewish concentration camp (in the book, the camp is identified as Auschwitz).  The story-line unfolds as though we are seeing the events happen through the wide-eyed naive eyes of Bruno, the eight-year-old son of the commandant.  Bruno quite accidentally forms an unknowing friendship with another 8 year old boy, but this boy, the boy in the striped pajamas on the other side of the fence, is a Jew. Bruno is completely ignorant of what is happening in the camp, which he believes to be a farm. When the commandant's wife realizes that the camp is a death camp, (apparently she too is blissfully unaware of the purpose of the camp), she has a falling out with her husband and demands to take the children away.  On the very day they are set to leave, events occur that lead to the climactic and sobering ending.

While thoroughly improbable in terms of the plot, in my opinion, this film still packs a powerful punch.  Critics, many of them Jewish critics, assailed this film for its improbability and for the naivete of the characters, in effect implying that the typical German citizens of the day did not know the meaning or intent of the death camps.  This is a valid criticism, but in the film's defence, this again is NAZI Germany seen through the eyes of a boy.  It is not meant to be a film that exposes all the evils of the Jewish Final Solution.  The film's ending is quite a bit different from the book's ending, but the effect is just as powerfully moving and sobering.

This film is definitely not suitable for children up to age 13.

The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is a movie that starts out with an 8 year boy named Bruno. Bruno's family was living in Berlin during WWII. While Bruno and his 13 year old sister go to school, their father is a high ranking soldier in the Nazi army. As time goes on, Bruno's father gets a promotion and is forced to move to German countryside. As the family moves into their new house, Bruno is informed that he is to be confined in the small fenced area surrounding their house. As life calms down, from his window, Bruno sees what he believes to be a farm with a chimney which occasionally flares black smoke into the air. Bruno confronts his parent asking why everyone is wearing striped pajamas on the farm he can see from his window. Covering the truth, his parents say they don't know. Eventually curiosity overpowers Bruno as he heads out into the back yard to explore the farm. Bruno approaches the fence and we learn the so called farm is actually a concentration camp. Behind the fence Bruno meets an eight year old boy Jewish boy named Shmuel. As the story progresses, these two become friends and Bruno sneaks out every spare chance he has to meet his friend.

The positive
This was an interesting movie because of a few factors. Rather than being another story of a Jewish family undergoing WWII; this movie demonstrates the difficulties of a German family during the same period. The story was well planned out and made you think. The acting was good and made you want to see what was going to happen next.

The Negative
What I didn't like were some segments in the movie. The beginning was slow and only got to the point in the middle of the movie. A lot of scenes where dragged out too long. By this I mean that there were a lot of parts where you sat down and told yourself "well". Scenes lasted for minutes when the boys just sat down and looked at each other saying only a few words.

Overall this was a good movie to watch. It not only shows the perspective of the Jews but also the perspective of the Germans. In this story, Bruno is acting as humanity ignoring the evil right before his eyes. Many non - Jews during the Holocaust acted like Bruno ignoring the wicked truth that was displayed in front of them.
One of the mst heart breaking movies I have seeing. It's a must see! Me and my daughter were crying thru out the whole movie.

Just echoing the sentiments of everyone else: it's a thought-provoking and emotional film, but not in the slightest historically accurate. Critics say that its fairytale plot over-simplifies/trivializes/commercially exploits the Holocaust; and that by allowing impossible events to take place or glossing over critical facts, less informed audiences might assume concentration camps weren't nearly as bad as they are.

Although I think the latter is an especially dangerous line to cross, I defend the film for what it is--the narrative of a sheltered boy. His innocence isn't meant to symbolize/defend people who pretend they didn't know what was happening at the time--his misinformation is just that of a child whose mother attempts to conceal the truth. After all, the movie is MEANT to exist through the naivete of a child's world.

If you want accuracy, go read a memoir instead of a fantastical distortion written in a few days by an author with no connection to the Holocaust--if you think the subject is too grim for fairytales, this might upset you. If you want tweens to understand that time period, I would rather recommend "I Have Lived A Thousand Years"; this isn't the type of movie to learn from. Otherwise, "The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas" is a must-watch emotional 'what-if' historical fiction with superb acting and character development.
The movie did a very good job of showing the emotion, thoughts and attitudes in the Holocaust situation.  The ending is very gripping and heart wrenching.

The DVD of the Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is based on the book of the same name by John Boyne. The basic story is that of Bruno, the nave and innocent son of the camp commandant of a Jewish concentration camp (Auschwitz). Bored with the lack of playmates, Bruno goes exploring and finds a boy in striped pyjamas on the other side of a high fence, and makes friends, with tragic consequences. The movie follows the basic tenet of the book, but differs on some minor points, (certainly, Shmuel looked less like a starved Jew than Bruno did). The scenes are well-acted, and Asa Butterfield played his role of Bruno especially well. I found the plummy English accent a little off-putting. It has a dramatic, Hollywood-style ending.

All of the actors do a great job and the story is engrossing. There are films that you guess the ending before it happens and you are either still intrigued or you are somewhat disengaged, here I was fully engaged and pleased with the result. Give it a watch and you might find yourself still thinking about it days later.

I was stand-in and a photo double for Asa in the upcoming Ender's Game--excellent young actor.  I would recommend to all.  The juxtaposition of his innocence and the cruelty of those around him truly stir an emotional response and sadness for all the atrocities committed.

The Holocaust obviously holds lessons that humanity has not yet learned.  Many fine films have explored those lessons.  This is one which expands our understanding through the eyes of Bruno, a small Aryan German boy whose father is promoted to become Commandant of a death camp.  Slipping out when his mother is gone shopping, Bruno walks through the woods to the camp and makes friends through the fence with a Jewish boy his age.  Bruno is not the only one in his family raising questions about the Nazi "solution."  His grandmother and his mother, each horrified as they learn the situation, rise to a form of revolt.  This is a fascinating and powerful film.

"The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a superb, deeply moving film.  It tells the story of two boys who become friends, despite tremendous social and physical barriers.  The story is told from the point of view of Bruno, the eight-year-old son of an SS Officer.  When the family must move due to Father's work, Bruno meets Schmuel, a boy like him, who is also eight.  But why does Schmuel live on such a strange farm?  And why do the farmers all wear pyjamas?

The acting is superb.  Asa Butterfield's performance as Bruno is particularly memorable; his portrayal of an eight-year-old boy contains just the right amount of innocence.  David Thewlis is excellent as Father; he comes across as a gentle man, while simultaneously making us hate him.  And Vera Farmiga is very believable in her role as Mother, who always knows more than she lets on to Bruno, and probably more than she admits to herself.

The story is mainly told from Bruno's point of view.  Thus, most of the atrocities take place off-screen.  Still, the movie manages not to downplay the horror of the Holocaust.  The audience always knows what is really going on, at least if they have any familiarity with the history at all.  Somehow, the film manages to be deeply disturbing without being graphic at all.

As others have noted, the film is unrealistic.  The fence around camp, for instance, seems to be strangely unguarded.  However, unlike other Holocaust films such as Schindler's List, this movie does not aim for realism.  Instead, it is highly symbolic.  Symbols of the holocaust permeate the film.  In one scene, a pile of naked dolls invokes the images of the Holocaust that we have all seen (piles of hair, shoes, eyeglasses, corpses).  And the electric fence reminds us that, whatever barriers are created between different peoples, the innocence of children will always surmount them.  It feels almost like a parable or fable (it's short length is appropriate in this regard).  As such, the realism is sometimes sacrificed for the sake of the plot.  But if we can suspend our disbelief, the true horror of the Holocaust will become even more apparent.  The symbolism says everything; the whole message of the film is contained in one shot in which two characters hold hands.

Finally, I will offer my take on the age-appropriateness of the film.  Some people believe that this film is a good way to introduce kids to the Holocaust.  I disagree.  I think kids should first see real images of the Holocaust and learn the real history before viewing a work of fiction (especially one that does not aim for historical accuracy).  Since the atrocities normally take place off camera, and much of the plot is implied rather than overtly stated, I think it would only confuse kids who haven't already been introduced to the subject-matter.  That said, if kids do have a good understanding of the Holocaust already, I think they should view this film.  They will be disturbed by it, but that's exactly what any film about the Holocaust should do.

Overall, I highly recommend this film.  I think anyone old enough to have learned the history of the Holocaust should see it.  Literally, it's a story about two boys who become friends despite tremendous social and physical barriers.  But the image at the end reminds us that it stands for something much bigger, and of the millions of innocents who suffered a terrible fate.

Powerful.  Moving.  Wonderfully written, produced, directed and acted.  You'll look a long time before you see child actors doing a better job.  This one will touch you deeply.  It's a keeper! This is one like that--a long overdue feeling.  Well done!

This film is a prodigy of horror wrapped up in love and that horror destroys this love forever by making it eternal in death.

Two eight year old boys meet, one on the free side of the fence, the other one on the camp side of the fence of a "work camp" (a nice name indeed for a Konzentration Kamp) for Jews just when the final solution is introduced. In Germany

I will neglect the side of the Commandant of the camp who is a SS and yet also has a personal life, a wife, two children, parents, a father who is on the good side and a mother who is clearly critical. A promotion for a SS officer is to become a camp Commandant and do, under strict secrecy, what is expected from him: to build a better German nation without any Jews, and if possible a world in the image of that German nation.

The film shows very well how the whole ideology is built on propaganda, which is a pack of lies, or ,if you prefer a pack of lying wolves that are after you to get your souls down into hell, in the name of the Greater future of the German nation. There is not much to say about the details of that machine. The details are there, clear and obvious. No comment, just cry with rage at such dumb inhumanity, really for both sides, the German nation itself and their victims.

The film is a lot more interesting with the eight year old son of that SS Commandant who escapes from the home of Herr Kommandant to  explore the forest behind the mansion and come to the fence where he discovers an eight year old Jewish boy who is hungry and sad, Shmuel. Shmuel has nothing to learn about the life outside the camp, but the other boy, Bruno, has to discover what the camp is and that it is no YMCA simmer camp. That takes time and a treason in the middle, but boys will be boys and they will invent a project to come together. Since Shmuel cannot come to the outside why not Bruno going into the camp.

And that will be the drama. No survivors please with the final solution, and frankly it's better like that. Which of the two boys could have survived without being damaged for life, or till death ensues.

And the film can end on the tears of the mother and sister and on the despair of the SS Commandant of a father. We will not be given the logical end for him after such a tragedy. Death at times can be sweet and desirable.

This is a masterpiece of poignancy even if suspense (who cares about suspense in a subject we all know by heart and regret with all our hearts) is rather light because boys will be boys and boys have always been boys. And love, or call it friendship if you prefer being a prude, has no limits, no divides, no abyss in the middle. Love is unified by definition and love comes no matter what and is for life and death. Happy are those who can share a life full of discoveries and then a death full of satisfaction. I am afraid the two boys met in death with apprehension and fear but a lot of courage in their acceptance of that fate as being a fate in which they can hold hands, and they did, naked under the fumes of the death-inflicting shower.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

I have watched the Boy In The Striped Pajamas a few times. This copy was a gift for a friend,purchased from Amazon.comVery vivid and informative film. The young boys in the film were excellent.

It is quite possible that more has been written and filmed about The Holocaust than any other historical event. Not just in regard to hard research, but many of the world's finest novelists have fictionalized the story, film makers have touched upon the subject, playwrights, composers, painters and poets. If there has been a way to express the shock- and shock is an understatement in this case- it has been attempted.
 John Boyne, a gifted and now internationally known Irish author, wrote the book "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas" in about two weeks time. As he said, in order to maintain "the voice," once he began he was afraid to stop. The same is true when reading it- we are compelled to continue and it is evident from early in the book that Boyne has disguised the terminal words so that it can apply to any and all of the other holocausts' that occurred prior to and after this one. In fact, only once does Boyne choose to use a "telling" word; on page 54 one of the officers says, "Heil Hitler" but then we are told that the boy assumed that this was like saying, "Well, goodbye for now and have a pleasant afternoon."
  Mark Herman, under the umbrella of both Miramax and BBC Films set forth to create this book effectively for film- a difficult task given that so much of the emotional swtruggle is internal and difficult to show on film, but he managed it and did so beautifully. Becauswe this film is in the smae catagoiry (in regard to quality) as "Sophie's Choice" I couldn't give it five stars- that doesn't mean that everyone shouldn't see this film. The small issues with the film are strongly outweighed by the genuis behind it- most of that genuis comes from the premise which leads us back to John Boyne.
 The boy, his name Bruno; his age eight and is able to say things with just his eyes that make the fiolm entiurely possible. Without Bruno (expeertly plkayed by Asa Butterfield) the filmn wouldnp;t work. His co -star, the nine yea old Schmuel on the other side of the fenvce ius played by Jack Scanlon who manages to exude sadnewss. The confussion that Bruno has regarding their situation is simply too complicated for Schmuel to explain. The finest performance in the film belongs to Vera Famiga, who plays Bruno's mother and wife to the Commandant at this camp. Like "Sophies Choice" and Meryl Streep's classic performance in that film, Farmiga builds and devlops over a period of ninety-three minutes until, at the apogee of the film we see her undderstanding reach fruition, just as the rain begins to fall. Her emotional breakdown at this point is raw, honest and something to which every parent can connect.
  The film score, composed and performed by James horner ("Titanic") is a character unto itselfl
The entire score is based upon a simple piece he composed that sounds like a gentle folks song. It is diatonic and in three quarter time. He utilizes synthesiers as well as wind instruments to add omonious irony to his music (the synthesisisers were expertly prograqmmed by Ian Underwood and Aaron Martin; the music editor was Dick Bernstein. The score builds momentum and continues, often at battle with itself, disploaying conflict between the characters as well as the situation itself. The music reaches it end with the film on a perfect ubnison which echos, just as the movie does.
 The innocence and ignorance of this young boy is as critical to the brilliance of this work as the story of the Titanic. (I speak not just of Cameron's film, but Maury Yeston's musical, "a Night to Remember" and the three other films made between 1938 and 1984) Herin is a tool where the audience not only knows so much more than Bruno, but that we are anticipating the sadness that ends the film. So we are prepared to cry but when the end does come, it is so shockiung that we aren;t ablke to cry; it';s not possiblke, this ending, though we've taken every step with these two boys and, of courwe (nbecause of our knowledge of what really happened) we know all too well that the ending is quite feasible.
 This film is by no means a "Sophie's Choice" though the horror is just as shocking, but few situations in cinematic history have been able to achieve what "Sophie's Choice" did. Still, the two films use a similar foundation but are about very different things. Where the ending is horrifyingly shocking and, like  "Sophie's Choice," completely unexpected (who in fact could have imagined an ending such as this one) the poignancy of "The Boy In Striped Pajamas" makes it impossible for this film- and the fame it will generate - to be satirized in any way. Because the innocence and ignorance, as a result of the way his parents have shielded Bruno, is a metaphor for the way in which the population who was aware of the death camps were inactive; complacent and how the same continues to occur day after day from the beginning of recorded time to the continued genocide in Darfur- the world's largest death camp- to which the UN has placed sanctions against while The full force of the American military tore apart Iraq in search of Weapons of Mass Destruction.
 The current political winds in the United States suggest that Gay Americans and Female Americans are just as vulnerable. All of these circumstances suggest that you could very well be next. John Boyne's book manages to suggest all of this is his two hundred page fable using a modicum of brilliantly chosen words. His ending:
 John Boyle has sub-titled his book, A Fable" and it is. His final words are like a double edged sword:
 "And that's the end of the story of Bruno and his family. Of course all of this
 happened a long time ago and nothing like that could ever happen again.
  Not in this day and age."

The irony of this ending reminds us that this is a fable, but more so, it makes us stop and think of the responsibility that we all owe to anyone who has been maltreated, either in the form of Bruno, Anne Frank, Sophie Zawotoski or Carol Stewart, Amy Fitzpatrick, Dave Pelzer and the millions of others.
  As a parent I would have watched this film with both of my daughters as early as sixth grade. Perhaps earlier. Those things that they d0o not understand will gloss over them; they will ask the right questions at the right times and it would be very wise to prepare a parental lesson plan for this because our children must learn of the Hollocaust and by far, this is the best way to introduce it to them I've seem to date. After this, they can read Anne Frank's diary and collefctively with the schools curriculum, they can see. but as we all learneed from Jonathan Demme's "silence of the Lambs" what the film doesn;t show and is left for our minds to create is often more horrific than a John Carpenter slaher film.
  The filmn is not able to end with the same impact as the book, but the ending is still remarkably powerful, filled with painful irony and one image that we watch for a few moments longer than we wish to as we see that there really was no other way this story could end.

What a movie!  It was quite compelling and very well done.  I sat in silence for a good five minutes after it was over,  "shaken" by the story and reflecting tragedies of the Holocaust.

A wonderfully made movie, it's all about the characters and story and being taken in. It is awfully heartbreaking though.

I have read the book and now watched the movie and I felt the same way about both. It's okay. The story itself is really good, I think. The execution in both the book and movie is good overall, but flawed. I'll try to focus on the movie here. My main problem with the movie involves acting.

The boy who plays Shmuel is not great. Plus, they chose a boy with a chubby face to play a Jew in a concentration camp. Kind of odd. There was zero chemistry between Bruno and Shmuel. They're supposed to be best friends, but they seemed fairly indifferent to each other for the most part.

Bruno's mother and father, played by Vera Farmiga and David Thewlis, were by far the best part of this movie. I love Vera in just about everything and this was no exception. Perhaps if the young actors in this movie learn from these two, they'll become great actors someday.

I'm very conflicted about this movie. For one thing, it's hard to see Professor Lupin (David Thewlis) playing an SS officer. Sure, he's cute little Bruno's father, and that voice is clearly the same one with which Lupin addressed Harry Potter. But he develops a rather hard edge as a necessary part of his job as Commander of a death camp. And his very handsome young driver (Henry Kingsmill, whom I KNOW I have seen somewhere before, but don't know where) also gets a pretty sharp edge, in part to compensate for an "unpatriotic" father who went to Switzerland at the time of the rise of the Nazis.

Bruno and his family lived in a perfectly marvelous old house in Berlin, where his family was obviously important. His parents tried to make "moving to the country" sound great when they went to put Father in charge of the "work camp," which Bruno at first took to be a farm. It's strange, though, because all the farmers wear striped pajamas. The house is starkly modern, and I suspect brand new. But it's large and they have several servants, so what's the kid's problem? He's bored. He's even more bored when he finds that he and his older sister are to have a tutor instead of going out to school.

Bruno is terribly bored because he's not allowed to go beyond the front courtyard of their home, which is surrounded by a steel fence. Guarded by soldiers, presumably because his father is so important. He's not even supposed to be in the back yard, but he's a natural explorer, and so he explores, and discovers a window in a storage shed that gives him access to the wooded area behind the house. This in turn leads him to a tall fence strung with barbed wire, where near the fence sits a boy just his age who is named Shmuel. He'd never heard of anyone named Shmuel before, but then Shmuel had never heard of anyone named Bruno before, so they are even on that. Both being lonely, they make friends.

We who know what the camp was all about are aware that this friendship can be dangerous for both boys, but we're into the last 10 or 15 minutes of the film before we find out just how dangerous. Of course I'm not going to give it away. I'm just going to give it four stars.

A very touching story, reinforcing the fact that children do not notice the external differences that adults do.  Sad, but true....

An SS Officer in Berlin receives a promotion and heads for the country to command a death camp. While the name of the death camp is not mentioned, the only death camp with four crematoriums was Auschwitz. His wife, daughter, and son come with him. The house chosen for the Commandant's family is a far stretch from the high society living in Berlin and the  "help" are Jews imprisoned in a close by camp. At first glance, Bruno, the 8-yr old son calls the camp a farm and proceeds to befriend an 8 yr old Jew named Smule while exploring. Through the electical fence they begin to communicate, both talking about their present environments. Gretl, the daughter, befriends a young SS soldier who brings her Nazi magazines which eventually cover the walls of her bedroom. Both Bruno and Gretl are tutored by an elder teacher who educates them on select German history. It is clear the Commandants wife, Else, just wants a good home for her family. One day the young SS soldier vaguely comments that the smell coming from the nearby Chimneys are Jews burning. Else is sickened by this admission and confronts her husband. Else represents the German polis that had no clue to the final solution and finds herself in a nation and a place she detests. She has ample compassion however to genuinely thank a prisoner who used to be a physician who took care of her son in a fall.

The Commandants mother, who vocally did not support the Hitler regime dies in a bombing campaign. The Fuhrer has sent a card of regret which lays on her corpse before being placed in the ground. Else motions to remove the card but her husband moves her hand away swiftly. Meanwhile, Bruno continues to bring food to Smule. One day to Bruno's surprise Smule is in his house cleaning glassware. They greet each other as friends and Smule is offered pastry. The young SS soldier comes in demanding where Smule got the pastry. Bruno did not back up his friend out of fear and Smule pays the price. The next time Bruno saw Smule he had an injury to his eye. To make up for the betrayal Bruno agrees to search for Smule's father who is missing. This event would have to happen quickly as Else persuaded her husband to let her take the children away from the camp. Bruno took a sandwich and headed for the camp. Smule gave Bruno a set of "striped pajamas" and Bruno came through the fence by digging a hole. The young boys go running thru the camp looking for Smule's father. In the midst of this it starts to rain and a group of men and boys are rounded up and taken to the fake shower room. Bruno and Smule are in this group. They are made to undress and are herded into the gas chamber. The gas chamber door is bolted shut. After about five minutes the verbal quakes are silenced. Meanwhile, Bruno's family searches vociferously in fear and eventually finds Bruno's clothes. Else is inconsolable. The Commandant runs through the camp but comes to the reality that Bruno, his son, was gassed. The Commandant's expression is trance-like as the rain pours down on his clean pressed SS uniform.

I'm not sure that the film is entirely possible. I doubt this ever actually happened, though I suppose it might have. But the story has a big impact. It touches on divisions between members of the family, and conflicts between German soldiers. It reminds the viewer that not all of Germany thought that what happened during the Holocaust was good, or even right. Then again, it also shows the viewer that the opposition did not have much of a voice. The government would quickly squash down any discontent. It also focuses a small amount on propoganda that was being fed to the German population, reminding them that the Jews were evil and responsible for the state of the nation (making the patriots happy), and cast a happy life on the 'work camps', painting them as lovely places with nice food, and sports (keeping the bleeding-heart critics happy). I think it was nice to include the real picture, as it gave credibility to the film. The German population really did have a real clue as to the horrors that went on in the camps right away. Once they realized, there was little anyone could do. The government control had grown too strong, and the people bowed beneath that control.

Excellent plot that held the attention of the audience in pointing out the horror of the concentration camps. The characters are believable and display a chills view of the war.

I believe that there are plenty of true stories about the Holocaust that are riveting enough for the big screen. Why make one about a story that is so unrealistic? I don't often review movies so I hope the reader can forgive me for an incomplete and sub-par review but I just watched this movie and felt moved enough to share my thoughts.

First of all at the party with all the pomp and circumstance for the German commander when he gets promoted, would they be playing American Jazz? Were Nazi's big fans of the Jazz movement? I'm not even sure how music that 'jazzy' would have been recieved in the States for the time period, maybe I'm nit-picking there. Here is a quote from Wikipedia, took me 3 seconds to look up: "The Nazi regime pursued and banned the broadcasting of jazz on German radio, partly because of its African roots and because many of the active jazz musicians were of Jewish origin; and partly due to the music's certain themes of individuality and freedom. For the Nazis, jazz was an especially threatening form of expression. An anti-jazz radio broadcast From the Cake Walk to Hot sought a deterrent effect with "particularly insisting musical examples." It's hard for me to believe at such an official and elegant party they would be playing jazz/swing music anywhere in the world, let alone Nazi Germany.

Secondly did children in concentration camps have time to lounge about? Were there large area of fence that were not under watch from some sort of guard on foot or tower? If someone were caught stealing they would just get hit in the face and told not to do it again?

Thirdly didn't the Nazi's tell relatives that they were gaurding over a prisoner camp, that the people in the camp were prisoners? It seems very unrealistic that the Grandparents would have the details that it was an extermination camp for Jews, from what I understand very few people knew beforehand exactaly what was going on and it was naturally someting that the Nazi's wanted to keep secret. I suppose a spouse of a commanding officer could have found out, but the whole way it came about in the movie seemed fake. Would the wife really have been shaken by the fact that there was a crematorium on the grounds and it was used on occasion? I would have liked to see someting a little more realistic; the husband arguing that they are prisoners and that a lot of people die in war time, maybe the wife buying that for a while and then confronting him when the creamatorium operates day and night and having her say how many criminals are there in Europe?

I know the film had an important message and a powerful ending, but I'm not happy that such liberties with reality were taken with this story.

I would not presume to give this movie a very thought provoking and long review, as it was this story was based on fiction.

I personally enjoyed this film, it warmed my heart in many many ways, including forcing me to think what if I were the one on either side of the fence. You have to put yourself outside the realm of reality when watching this film though and realize that what is going on is the author trying to emphasize the holocaust in a fictional manner as these personal events happening in the midst of a tragedy never occurred.

My criticism stems from the fact that there were so many family's, so many loved ones and so many lives involved in this human tragedy that the author could have easily written something of a true nature.. The author could have found many stories from true accounts or lets just say, for the sake of thought.. What if the film makers emphasized more that this was based on fiction and not almost sold this as real, I myself had to look this up to find the truth. I would have liked to see money put into a film telling one of the many many true to life stories that were and not a heartwarming story that yanks your heart at the end..

 Please do not get me wrong as this is a wonderful story that shows you the what if's of human tragedy but their is no evidence to support that something like this even remotely happened and I for one would like to be told if this were true from the beginning.. It seems that the film makers and author really want to sell you on this story to the point of neglecting to tell you that it is fiction with the only fact being what it is based around. I see nothing astounding in this work, just another film to make you cry so you may say "BRAVO" in the end

I would rather, make a suggestion... Watch "The Island on Bird Street", it is just as heartwarming (Maybe more) and based on a true story
This has been one of the best movies I have ever seen. Don't hesitate on watching it, It is definitely  worth to watch. 100% Recommended

upon how we are living our lifes according to God's Laws.
Sad movie but very well executed! Story of how humans can be deceitful and selfish, even from a young age

The razor's edge cuts through this powerful WWII Holocaust drama "Il Bambino Con Il Pigiama A Righe" with no remorse. We witness firsthand in this film the atrocities of one concentration camp and the normalcy of one family, a father Ralf (the SS officer who is camp commandant), the mother Elsa (who believes her husband supervises a labor camp, then finds out it is a death camp), their 13 year old daughter Gretel (who naively embraces Nazi propaganda), and their 8 year old son Bruno (who secretly befriends an 8 year old Jewish boy named Shmuel in the camp and determines on his own - that the propaganda is false based on his own observations of Jewish families and his conversations with the other boy).

This revelation by Bruno drives the plot. His friendship with Shmuel grows into a strong bond, much closer than his relationship with his father, mother, or sister. Bruno sneaks out to see his friend, risks being caught - all the while he listens to his father's deceitful, self-righteous, dogmatic words about people in the camp. He draws his own conclusions. Bruno begins to see his own 'noble obligation' through the humble perspective of his close friend, a Jewish boy. He becomes our hero in the truest sense, because he does not accept the lies, deceit, hypocrisy, murderous intent, or tyranny of the Nazis and their judgement upon Jews. He makes up his own mind. He rises above the civilized evil presented to him - to go into the oven of death with his close friend. Bruno's sacrifice with Shmuel of life itself becomes a testament of will power and grace, apart from the horrors of the camp and its method of execution. As an audience, we grow in stature by witnessing this epic tragedy through the eyes of innocent children.

In this film we sense doom, dread, agony, hopelessness, and suffering beyond human comprehension. We know from "Schindler's List" and other concentration camp films - what awaits these inmates. Then out of the severity of the storyline - we observe the extreme humility and understanding on the part of two boys. We are allowed to empathize with them, even as their friendship is separated by barbed wires and guard dogs; even as they await the executioner's death knoll together - which is a numbing thought in and of itself. Depth of character and plot are evenly pervasive. Dramatic irony is present as tyranny wears the mask of a somewhat civilized military officer with a somewhat normal family who ultimately must realize that he has unintentionally given the order to exterminate his own son. The agonized wailing of his wife Elsa echoes the silent acceptance of Jewish mothers who are herded into the ovens. Superb performaces from seasoned character actors and actresses make this film a rare accomplishment for its director and crew. The unities are adhered to with discipline in the filmmaking sense.

La orilla de la navaja corta por este drama poderoso de Holocausto de l Segunda Guerra Mundial "El Nino con el Pijama de Rayas" con ningn remordimiento. Presenciamos directamente en esta pelcula las atrocidades de un campo de concentracin y la normalidad de una familia, un padre Ralf (el oficial de S que es comandante de campamento), la madre Elsa (que cree que su marido supervisa un campo de trabajos forzados, entonces hallazgos fuera ello son un campo de exterminio), su de 13 aos de edad hija Gretel (que ingenuamente abraza propaganda nazi), y su de 8 aos de edad hijo Bruno (que ofrece amistad a en secreto un 8 ao El chico judo viejo denomin Shmuel en el campamento y determina solo - que la propaganda es falsa basada en sus propias observaciones de familias judas y sus conversaciones con el otro chico).

Esta revelacin por Bruno maneja el complot. Su amistad con Shmuel crece en un bono fuerte, mucho ms cerca que su relacin con su padre, con la madre, o con la hermana. Bruno sale a hurtadillas para ver a su amigo, los riesgos para ser agarrados - todo el tiempo l escucha sus palabras engaosas, farisaicas y dogmticas de padre acerca de personas en el campamento. Dibuja sus propias conclusiones. Bruno comienza a ver su propia "obligacin noble" por la perspectiva humilde de su amigo ntimo, un chico judo.

Llega a ser nuestro hroe en el sentido ms verdadero, porque l no acepta las mentiras, el engao, la hipocresa, asesino atento, ni la tirana de los nazis y su juicio sobre judos. Hace su propia mente. Sobrepasa la mal civilizada presentada a l - entrar el horno de la muerte con su amigo ntimo. El sacrificio de Bruno con Shmuel de la vida misma llega a ser un testamento de enchufar y agraciar, aparte de los horrores del campamento y su mtodo de ejecucin. Como una audiencia, nosotros crecemos en la estatura presenciando esta tragedia pica por los ojos de nios inocentes.

En esta pelcula nosotros presentimos destino, el terror, la angustia, la desesperanza, y sufriendo ms all de la comprensin humana. Sabemos de la "Lista de Schindler" y otras pelculas de campo de concentracin - lo que aguarda a estos presos. Entonces fuera de la severidad del argumento - observamos que la humildad extrema y comprendiendo en la parte de dos chicos. Somos permitidos compenetrar con ellos, an como su amistad es separada por alambres y perros guardianes con pas; an como aguardan otero de la muerte del verdugo juntos - que es un pensamiento entumecido de por s.

La profundidad de carcter y complot es uniformemente penetrante. La irona dramtica es presente como la tirana lleva la mscara de un oficial militar algo civilizado con una familia algo normal que ltimamente debe darse cuenta de que ha dado sin querer la orden a exterminar a su propio hijo. Gemir agonizado de su esposa Elsa resuena la aceptacin silenciosa de madres judas que son conducidas en manada en los hornos. Magnfico performaces de actores de carcter y actrices experimentados hace esta pelcula un logro raro para su director y la tripulacin. Las unidades son adheridas a con disciplina en el sentido de cinematografa.

The razor's edge cuts through this powerful WWII Holocaust drama "Il Bambino Con Il Pigiama A Righe" with no remorse. We witness firsthand in this film the atrocities of one concentration camp and the normalcy of one family, a father Ralf (the SS officer who is camp commandant), the mother Elsa (who believes her husband supervises a labor camp, then finds out it is a death camp), their 13 year old daughter Gretel (who naively embraces Nazi propaganda), and their 8 year old son Bruno (who secretly befriends an 8 year old Jewish boy named Shmuel in the camp and determines on his own - that the propaganda is false based on his own observations of Jewish families and his conversations with the other boy).

This revelation by Bruno drives the plot. His friendship with Shmuel grows into a strong bond, much closer than his relationship with his father, mother, or sister. Bruno sneaks out to see his friend, risks being caught - all the while he listens to his father's deceitful, self-righteous, dogmatic words about people in the camp. He draws his own conclusions. Bruno begins to see his own 'noble obligation' through the humble perspective of his close friend, a Jewish boy. He becomes our hero in the truest sense, because he does not accept the lies, deceit, hypocrisy, murderous intent, or tyranny of the Nazis and their judgement upon Jews. He makes up his own mind. He rises above the civilized evil presented to him - to go into the oven of death with his close friend. Bruno's sacrifice with Shmuel of life itself becomes a testament of will power and grace, apart from the horrors of the camp and its method of execution. As an audience, we grow in stature by witnessing this epic tragedy through the eyes of innocent children.

In this film we sense doom, dread, agony, hopelessness, and suffering beyond human comprehension. We know from "Schindler's List" and other concentration camp films - what awaits these inmates. Then out of the severity of the storyline - we observe the extreme humility and understanding on the part of two boys. We are allowed to empathize with them, even as their friendship is separated by barbed wires and guard dogs; even as they await the executioner's death knoll together - which is a numbing thought in and of itself. Depth of character and plot are evenly pervasive. Dramatic irony is present as tyranny wears the mask of a somewhat civilized military officer with a somewhat normal family who ultimately must realize that he has unintentionally given the order to exterminate his own son. The agonized wailing of his wife Elsa echoes the silent acceptance of Jewish mothers who are herded into the ovens. Superb performaces from seasoned character actors and actresses make this film a rare accomplishment for its director and crew. The unities are adhered to with discipline in the filmmaking sense.

Il margine del rasoio taglia attraverso questo dramma di Olocausto di seconda guerra mondiale potente "Il Bambino la Truffa Il Pigiama UN Righe" con nessun rimorso. Testimoniamo di prima mano in questo film le atrocit di un campo di concentramento e la normalit di una famiglia, un Ralf di padre (il S l'ufficiale che  il comandante di campeggio), l'Elsa di madre (che crede che suo marito sovrintenda un campo di lavoro, une poi scoperte fuori da  un campeggio di morte), il loro 13 anno vecchio Gretel di figlia (che abbraccia ingenuamente il proganda di nazista), ed il loro 8 anno vecchio Bruno di figlio (che aiuta segretamente un 8 anno Il vecchio ragazzo Ebreo ha nominato Shmuel nel campeggio e determina di propria iniziativa - che la propaganda  falso basato sulle sue proprie osservazioni di famiglie Ebree e le sue conversazioni con l'altro ragazzo).

Questa rivelazione da Bruno guida il complotto. La sua amicizia con Shmuel cresce in un vincolo forte, molto pi vicino del suo rapporto con suo padre, sua madre o sua sorella. Bruno si insinua fuori per vedere il suo amico, i rischi essendo presi - tutto il mentre ascolta le parole ingannevoli,, farisaici, dogmatici delle persone nel campeggio di suo padre. Disegna le sue proprie conclusioni. Bruno inizia a vedere il suo proprio "obbligo nobile" attraverso la prospettiva umile del suo amico vicino, un ragazzo Ebreo. Diventa il nostro eroe nel pi vero senso, perch non accetta le bugie, l'inganno, l'ipocrisia, l'intento omicida o la tirannia dei nazisti ed il loro giudizio sugli Ebrei. Inventa la sua propria mente.  superiore al civilizzato malvagio presentato a lui - di andare nel forno di morte con il suo amico vicino. Il sacrificio di Bruno con Shmuel di vita diventa un testamento di alimenter ed orner, a prescindere dagli orrori del campeggio ed il suo metodo di esecuzione. Come un pubblico, cresciamo nella statura testimoniando questa tragedia epica attraverso gli occhi di bambini innocenti.

In questo film percepiamo la sorte, teme, l'agonia, la disperazione e soffrendo oltre la comprensione umana. Sappiamo dall' "Elenco dello Schindler" e gli altri film di campo di concentramento - ci che attende questi internati. Poi fuori da della severit della trama - osserviamo l'umilt estrema e capendo da parte di due ragazzi. Siamo consentiti identificarsi con loro, anche poich la loro amicizia  separata dai fili metallici dentellati e dai cani da guardia; anche poich attendono la collinetta di morte del carnefice insieme - che  un pensiero intorpidito in e di s. La profondit di carattere ed il complotto abbonda in questo film. L'ironia drammatica  attuale poich la tirannia indossa la maschera di un ufficiale un poco civilizzato militare con una famiglia un poco normale che deve realizzare in definitiva che ha dato involontariamente all'ordine per sterminare suo proprio figlio. Il gemere angosciato del suo Elsa di moglie risuona l'accettazione silenziosa di madri Ebree che sono guidato nei forni. Il performaces superbo dai caratteristi con esperienza e le attrici fa questo film una realizzazione rara per il suo direttore ed il suo equipaggio. Le unit sono aderite a con la disciplina nel senso di produzione cinematografica.
Absolutely a must see. Although a sad story, I think it should be read by every teenager or even adult. Touching and compassionate

I rented this through netflix and will be getting my own copy.  I didn't know anything about it.  It just seemed interesting.  As it's DVD only I'll urge them to move it to streaming so others might happen on it.

I grew deeply interested in the Holocaust maybe fifteen years ago while doing an edit on a friends novel, set in the time.  She wrote one chapter of the charaters ride in a boxcar to Auschwitz that I was reminded of each time one of the frequent freight trains passed by our house.  I knew of course what had happened before, but it personalized it, as one human beigns point of view, (especially since he knew what awaited them and many of the other didn't}  I started seeking out books written by survivors and the liberators and the ghastly black and white (later color) pictures took on a new life, about people.

This movie does the same.  I knew nothing about it but the short summary and wasn't sure what to expect, and was drawn in immedidatly.  Sure, there are inaccuracies.  The children would have been indoctrinated to a degree, the daughter most of all.  The boy is very much a child of war, witness the way his friends pretended a realistic view of how war is carried out.  And the husband, knowing his wife was uncertain and not completely patriotic, would have hid it better or been called and sent to the front himself.  But it isn't about that, its about the viseral experience.  When they arrive at the new house, with armed guards and a gate, when they see the stark almost prisonlike interior, you know what sort of a place they are.

Bruno is a dreamer, and dreamers tend to shut out certain perceptions.  And he's lonely.  His new friend knows what the place is, and spends time sitting alone.  Maybe in a different world they'd be very much alike.  And he still has his father.  You can see the panic starting to surface when his father dissapears.  The two boys make a connection through childhood with this magical spark.  Dreamers, in a harsh, terrible world, often pay the price of dreaming.

Not knowing anything about the end, I absolutely didn't expect it.  I was sure there would be *some* sort of reprieve.  It absolutely stunned me.  I would absolutely reccoment this film, but not for children.  But the end scene brings the body counts and the detains (portrayed VERY accurately) to a personal level.  They aren't statistics but real.

I have to wonder what happens to the family afterwards.  A commandant who allows that to happen would not be tolerated.  It would be too easy to figure out the mother was not a happy camper with the politics.  If your father leaving the counry gets you sent to the front, then what does this bring? That is the thing that works so well.  It makes me wonder, but its outside Bruno's knowing.  A mark of a good film is to keep you thinking after the end, but not going too far.

Absolutely deserves five stars.  I look forward to seeing it again, knowing, and see wht I pick up I didn't before.

I've watched many great film adaptations of books written about the Holocaust and how it affected all involved.  Yet, THE BOY IN THE STRIPPED PAJAMAS, was probably the most heart-breaking movie I've seen because it showed in chilling details how two young boys - one Jewish, one German, became innocent victims of Hitler's Nazis madness to exterminate Europe of non-Aryans.  The movie was all the more powerful and heart-wrenching in its portrayal of the hedonist perpetration of human extermination because the two main child characters [eight-year-old Shmuel, 'the boy in the stripped pajamas', and eight-year-old, Bruno 'the son of the Commandant responsible for the extermination camp were Shumel is held captive'] are exemplary in their roles of capturing children's naivety and inability to comprehend the unthinkable.

Other reviewers have written in great detail about the specifics of the plot.  It is multi-layered and complex, examining the the characters who portrayed participants and victims of a an evil event in recent history, and the effects it had on each.
