Instead, I prefer to focus my comments on why I believe this movie is so important.

In my opinion, we underestimate the innocence of young children and their gullibility, their 'magical thinking' to believe in an idealistic world, and the pureness of their hearts to believe the best in their parents; failing to see, imagine, or comprehend any flaws. Even when young children are exposed to the 'worse' of abusive conditions, most don't grasp the depth of their circumstances.  For this reason [among others] children are easily manipulated to do what they are told by predators; coerced to believe in angels and gifts when they obey, or condemned to be tormented by monstrous demons if they don't comply.

Because of the subtleties in the manner the scenes are directed, rather than the 'overtness' obvious to us as adults, the dialogue between Bruno and Shumel made this movie all the more chilling to watch.  As viewers, we watch their friendship blossom knowing they have already become unsuspecting victims.  Through the innocent and loyal camaraderie that we witness between Bruno and Shumel - two 'sacrificial lambs' - we discover the unimaginable horror, power, magnitude, and atrocity of the Holocaust.

THE BOY IN THE STRIPPED PAJAMAS is a movie to be watched by families who have teenagers.  It is a film I'll long remember.

Maizie Lucille James
January 14, 2012

I've read the book upon which this movie is based, and also reviewed it. The book makes for a thoughtful discussion on the Holocaust, though it did have some problems having to do with plot implausibilities. Yet despite all of that, I did think the book added some value to novels dealing with the Holocaust, especially in portraying the story from the 8-year-old German Aryan boy's point of view.

Now on to the movie - the story follows the book closely with some adaptations. Set during WW II, 8-year-old German Aryan, Bruno finds his carefree life in Berlin is about to come to an end as his father [David Thelis] has been promoted to the position of Kommandant thus necessitating the family's move to a rural outpost which is nameless. So, Bruno [Asa Butterfield], his 12-year-old sister Gretel [Amber Beattie], mother [Vera Farmiga] and dad make the move. Bruno is initially not impressed with his new surroundings - there are no other houses nearby and the children are not able to attend school, taught instead by a bigoted old tutor who subscribes to Nazi ideology. Bruno in the meantime has discovered a 'farm' close by and to his immense delight, meets another 8-year-old boy with the curious name of Schmuel [Jack Scanlon] who seems to have tons of 'friends' and has the luxury of wearing 'pajamas' all day. Though he is forbidden to explore the back of the house, Bruno makes clandestine visits to his friend, who sadly cannot play with him as they are separated by a barbed wire fence, which Bruno thinks is to keep the animals out. The pair's friendship grows every day, and Bruno begins to learn some disturbing things, such as the ill-treatment of Jews. In the meantime, Bruno's mother Ilse [Vera Farmiga] begins to fall apart as she makes some horrific discoveries of her own. The rest of the story deals with what happens to Bruno and Schmuel.

There are some plot implausibilities - the fact that Bruno is so incredibly naive about Jews and the ideology of hatred against them is hard to accept if only because most German Aryan boys of Bruno's age would have been in the Hitler Youth and thus exposed to such teachings. Bruno being a high-ranking Nazi officer's son would most certainly have been in the Hitler Youth as would his sister. Also, Ilse's naivete seems implausible. As for Schmuel, most young children were immediately selected for the gas chambers upon arrival, and it seems almost miraculous that Schmuel survived for as long as he did, and was able to meet Bruno so often without detection.

But, implausibilities aside, I still liked this movie - it manages to portray the innocence of children in a depraved world so very credibly, and this is largely due to Asa Butterfield's amazing performance as the naive Bruno whose eyes are slowly 'opened' to the cruelty evident around him. Jack Scanlon's Schmuel is also credible -the chemistry between the two boys is very real, and their friendship is altogether believable. Vera Farmiga's performance as the tormented Ilse is the most powerful adult performance in this movie - she delivers a finely-nuanced performance that makes us believe Ilse was truly horrified by what was being done to the Jews. The other adult male characters delivered rather weak performances - David Thewlis as the Kommandant was stiff in his role and seemed ill at ease for the most part, the sadistic Nazi driver seemed very much a one-dimensional character, and even the Jewish houseworker was not given much character development.

All in all, "Boy in the Striped Pajamas" succeeds in getting under one's skin and doesn't cop out with a happily ever after ending, for the climax is brutal and mind-numbing. The child actors' powerful performances enables the movie to address questions about humanity and man's capacity for evil.

This was a very well-made movie, with excellent acting, casting, camera-work, etc., but I can't get away from the fact that it was the most depressing movie I have ever watched.  I know that movies like this have to be made, and not every movie should have a happy ending, but I guess I just want to warn people about this.  This film is going to hit you hard, and stay with you for a long time.

This product was received as promised and without and scratches or blemishes. This is such a moving story and a few family members had not seen this movie so I thought it worthwhile to purchase. Great movie! Thanks for allowing our family to share the moment of this DVD!

I really enjoyed this movie.  It's very brutal at times.  But the actors do a brillant job telling the story.  In part of the story the mother has to choose what she knows is right against her husband who runs the camp where they gas the jews.  But what I really thought was brilliant in the movie was the friendship and the how you never know what going to happen unless you walk in someone else's shoes.  I would recommend this movie and let your teenagers watch it for history and to appreciate the life they live  here in the United States Freedom.

This one is a "sleeper" that I know as missed by most people.  It is a different kind of Holocaust movie.  It centers on a young boy (same actor from the movie "Hugo" 2011 movie) whose father is a high official in the Nazi Party.  They move near a concentration camp that the Dad is in charge of.  While secretly exploring the grounds, the adventurous and lonely boy discovers a fenced in area and another little boy in "pajamas" on the other side.  They develop a secret bond/friendship through the fence. I will say no more except that EVERYTHING about this movie is wonderful. Acting, writing, directing, photography.  This is a movie you will not forget, and will find yourself recommending to friends.
This  is  a excelent  movie  for  view,  because  is  a real  sad history.  You  know  how was  the  another side  the real life  in that time.

This movie was a very emotional and heartwarming story that touched on a really sad and horrendous time in the history of mankind. It was well writen and excellently acted. The ending was an emotional shocker that really leads anyone who watched or watches this movie to think. Well done.

I loved this thoughtful movie.  It left me a little sick at the end but it certainly made the point. Two little boys one is the son of the Commandant in charge of the death camp, the other a little Jewish inmate of the camp, become friends by talking through the barbed wire. The Commandant tries to keep hidden from his children what he really does ( that is put people to death), in keeping his children ignorant, he gets his son killed.  The son innocent and slightly  confused about the camp and barbed wire and seeking adventure, strikes up a friendship with a little boy on the other side of the fence. Ultimately the son and the little boy die together in the gas chambers built by the father, when the Commandant's son tries to help the other boy find his father by sneaking under the barbed wire posing as an inmate. The theme of the story is children have no bias about race, religion, or color unless it is taught to them by adults, and that hate and ignorance of any kind has devastating consequences. The film quality is excellent and, the acting is very good.

This is an excellent movie, mostly from a child's perspective.  It portrays the innocence of humanity and the evil that existed during the Holocaust.  This is an appropriate movie as well with no cussing or nudity, and the violence is seen however the viewer still knows what is happening.  I watched this with my children (9 & 10) and it was a good way to introduce the Holocaust without them seeing the extreme violence.

Sorry, I am a military history fanatic and I watched this movie recently with my daughter.  It is an interesting story, but it's about as historically accurate as Peter Pan or The Adventures of Winnie the Pooh.  This movie is decently made, but, the story is complete fantasy and absolutely ludicrous.  This movie is so poor, it's an insult to the intelligence of anyone who's studied German concentration camps at all.  There are far too many historical errors in this movie to list here, but all I can say is this is a work of complete fantasy and fiction - the events portrayed in this film COULD NOT have occurred at ANY German concentration camp at any time.

If the point of this movie is to make children identify with the holocaust, which is what it would seem to be, the film makers have done an injustice to everyone concerned.  This goal could have been easily obtained, but instead, they just made up an absolutely ridiculous story with an equally ridiculous ending.

Sorry to all of those who loved this film, but I didn't find it moving or touching, I couldn't get past the absurdity of the entire film to connect with the "moving" story it was supposed to be conveying.  There are FAR better films out there dealing with the Holocaust, DO NOT waste time watching this one.
This is quite simply "my kind of movie". Exremely well written, extremely well acted. It captures your imagination and your heart, plus holds your interest from start to finish.

The Boy in the Striped Pajamas provides a child's perspective on the Holocaust. This movie is masterfully crafted with a poignant narrative, which should be appreciated for its tremendous capability to acknowledge the immense tragedy of the Holocaust. It is through the eyes of a playful boy that the viewer will clearly see how atrocity doesn't even spare the most innocent.

Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author

This was an excellent movie but very sad. Makes you realize what these people went
thru and how horribly they were treated.  I would suggest this movie for adult viewing.

By Darrell Stoddard, darrellstoddard@gmail.com

This emotionally wrenching film deserves 10 Stars. Changed my life forever and a major part of my life was spent in motion pictures. The movie will change your life everlastingly too if you open your heart to a simple fictional story of a little German boy who befriends a Jewish boy through the barbed wire fence of a concentration camp.

My heart was ripped out, but I will be a more loving, gracious, forgiving person for having seen this sensitive and also horrifying motion picture. YES, as the reviewers have said: It is "historically inaccurate to the extreme." "It is total fiction." It is "ridiculously contrived." It is "all too absurd." It is "hard to swallow." It is "forced and artificial," and "The actors have British accents instead of German."

One critic posed the question, "Did Bruno's father in the end get what he deserved?" Such moralizing and such criticisms of the film make me wonder if those viewers of the film missed the unanswered questions of the Holocaust. How could it happen? How could so many good people allow it to happen?

The most insightful reviewer said, "What is appalling to me is reading all of the one-star reviews. I now see how the holocaust (shoah) could have taken place. All that is necessary is for a nation to be composed of and ruled by people with no feelings, bereft of human compassion and sensitivity, just like several of the reviewers here."

Great Art (even fiction) reveals to us "things as they really are". Through Bruno and his mother, we see through the eyes of Germans who were totally innocent until they came face to face with with the horrors of the "final solution." Most Europeans accepted the deportation of Jews, some not knowing what would be their fate and others even accepting the fate of Jews because it was so easy to blame Jewish Merchants and Jewish Bankers for World War 1 and for the collapse of the German economy. Savings were totally wiped out. It took 22 million German Marks to buy a loaf of bread. Though not the same, we can understand today how easy it would be to blame all Muslims for 9/11.

Through Bruno's sister we see how easy it was to indoctrinate an entire nation of German youth. A notable exception was the 17 year old Mormon boy, Helmuth Hubener, that resisted the 3rd Reich and was sentenced by a German Court for treason and beheaded by guillotine on October 27, 1942 at Pltzensee Prison in Berlin. (See his true story on Wikipedia!)

In this motion picture we see and learn how good men, good fathers, and good soldiers, putting military obedience ahead of even their mothers, wives and children, directed and became the executioners of millions of Jews. Even still photos of all the corpses, and eye witness accounts of the Holocaust do not give us that understanding.

Last, by identifying and seeing through the eyes of an innocent child, we learn from the film what it was like to be ordered into the gas chambers. No other motion picture, book, or document has ever, or ever will, capture that experience or the depth of those feelings like the film "Boy in the Stripped Pajamas."

Would that each viewer could become as a little child (Matthew 18:3), like Bruno, not judgmental, and not critical.  The Holocaust (like the film) is hard to believe but the gas chambers to kill and the ovens to burn bodies were real. I've seen them with my own eyes. I've been in the house made sacred by Anne Frank. My next door neighbor was one of the first U.S. soldiers into the Dachau Prison Camp, and my neighbor across the street served in the Danish Underground.

Let us resolve, NEVER AGAIN, not just in five languages, but in all the languages of the world. There were those in Germany that truly did not know what was happening to the Jews, but no other film answers for me how an entire nation could be led by one man to kill, or accept the killing, of so many. I will be forever haunted by the words, "If he had been your Fuehrer, you would have followed him too."  Although it is fiction, "Boy In the Striped Pajamas" reveals not the historical truth, but the TRUTH of Nazi Germany as it was.

FOOTNOTE: What follows regarding man's inhumanity to man is presented because HISTORY WILL REPEAT ITSELF IF WE DO NOT KNOW AND UNDERSTAND IT!

People today need to know that Hitler did not invent anti-semitism. It began with the crucifixion of Jesus Christ and has never ceased. It is mind boggling to learn that throughout history there have been innumerable and hundreds of attempts in many countries to kill all of the Jews. (See "Pogroms" on Google, then read the Wikipedia account.)

I was shocked beyond belief to read Martin Luther's anti Jewish sentiments published in 1543 (See "On the Jews and Their Lies - Wikipedia"  Luther's feelings about the Jews and what should be done to them were as vile and reprehensible, as any words spoken in Nazi Germany. Indeed, Luther's document may have been the blueprint for the Nazi Holocaust.

Seeing history repeat itself so many times makes us wonder if there is hope to save the Jews and the world from so much hate and killing. Pope John VI in 1965 issued his historic "Nostra Aetate" that expresses understanding, forgiveness and love for the Jews and for all religions.  Pope John Paul VI states in this history changing document that the death of Christ, "cannot be charged against all the Jews, without distinction, then alive, nor against the Jews of today." The age old doctrine behind all of the Pogroms which stated that "all Jews, past, present, and future were collectively guilty of the Crucifixion of Jesus," was officially revoked by a Catholic Pope! EVERYONE should read entirely the "Nostra Aetate" which is one of the most important documents in the history of mankind (It takes just a few minutes to read and can be found on Google)! The current Pope Benedict XVI who was forced to join the Hitler Youth as a child in Nazi Germany (in two books) has made a sweeping exoneration of the Jewish people for the death of Jesus Christ. There is hope for the world! These are history changing actions by two Catholic Popes. It would be well for everyone who wants the world to be a better place to thank Catholics for Pope John VI and Pope Benedict XVI.

We must be ever vigilant against condemning another. "Therefore thou art inexcusable, Oh man, whosoever thou art that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself: for thou that judgest doest the same things." (Romans 2:1). Jews who migrated to Israel after World War 11, themselves committed a Holocaust of the Palestinian people. Tens of thousands of Palestinians were killed and nearly one million were forced into refugee camps. "This is my Land. God gave this Land to me," was not justification for killing the Palestinians!

There is one notable voice in the Middle East that documents the atrocities by all three sides and seeks to reconcile Jews, Christians, and Muslims. Elias Chacour, a Palestinian Melkite Christian Priest has established a school in Ibillon near Galilee where Christians, Jews, Muslims, and Druze study side by side. More important than their secular studies, students learn to love their enemies. To bring peace to the Holy Land, Elias Chacour's book "BLOOD BROTHERS" SHOULD BE REQUIRED READING FOR EVERYONE.

Two unsung and less known heroes of the Holocaust are Irena Sendler and Raoul Wallenberg. Their stories should be told along with the stories of Oskar Schindler, Corrie Ten Boom, and Anne Frank. Irena Sendler was a Polish Catholic Social worker who saved more than 2500 Jewish Children from the Warsaw Ghetto. If you have any interest in the Holocaust, YOU MUST READ the inspiring story "Life in A Jar - The Irena Sendler Story" on Google. In 2007 when Sendler was still alive, she was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. Al Gore received the prize that year instead.

Raoul Wallenberg is credited with saving near 100,000 Hungarian Jews. At the peril of his life he defied the Nazis innumerable times. Read a summary of Wallenberg's unbelievable courage to save Hungarian Jews on Google: "Profile of a Leader: The Wallenberg Effect." See Wallenberg's complete story in the book "Righteous Gentile" available used from amazon.com from a number of book dealers for one cent plus $3.99 for shipping and handling.  EVERY reviewer gave the book 5 stars! Unlike Schindler, Wallenberg had only his humanity and no ulterior motive in saving Jews; and he probably saved more Jews than Schindler.

Few Motion pictures can compare to the book. The motion picture "Wallenberg A Hero's Story" is even equal to the book "Righteous Gentile"! Both the book and the movie will lift your very being to heaven. Man at his best is so good, so noble, so Christlike, that we would fain throw a cover over men and women when they are less. Mankind needs Hero's like Wallenberg to lift and redeem us. It will make anyone a better person to make the book or the motion picture a part of their life.

See all of my Reviews. I write only about books, events, or motion pictures that have changed the course of history or unforgettable books or motion pictures that will totally change peoples lives.

Darrell Stoddard, Founder - Pain Research Institute and saveusa.biz
Very good movie. Very somber at times and brings a person to tears. A picture that you keep in your memory for a long, long time!!!

"The boy in the stripped pajamas" was the saddest, most heartbreaking, movie that I have ever seen. Not just because it was an awful thing that happened. (and awful isn't the word to describe it.... nothing can) but to just imagine that this happened to men, women, old, and YOUNG. (All I could picture was my little sons...... and the worst part is, it is all true.

I think that everyone should see this movie. And I am willing to bet that you will walk away with a mixed set of emotions, from anger to sadness, to confusion, to blame, to guilt.

It will leave you speechless, and it will probably leave you with tears in your eyes, but it is worth it.

Watching this movie was the equivalent of watching a car accident about to happen. You know what's about to happen, you understand the dire consequences of what is about to happen, and understand the depth to which the lives of everyone involved will change, but the people actually involved are blessedly unaware. From the beginning, we can see that the friendship between Bruno and Shmuel is doomed, but because of their age and naivete, they are unable to see it. This movie was absolutely amazing. It did a fantastic job of expressing Bruno's initial state of unawareness, and his journey to opening his young eyes and seeing that something is not right. Although Bruno sees a lot of the hate that is going on, he doesn't understand much of what is going on, while the audience does. I would recommend this movie to anyone.

So this is a GREAT movie, but when I finally opened it to watch it won't play and I threw out the receipt so I'm pretty much stuck with it. I don't think it was the seller's fault, sometimes they won't play so I guess I'll be re-ordering.

The DVD of the Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is based on the book of the same name by John Boyne. The basic story is that of Bruno, the nave and innocent son of the camp commandant of a Jewish concentration camp (Auschwitz). Bored with the lack of playmates, Bruno goes exploring and finds a boy in striped pyjamas on the other side of a high fence, and makes friends, with tragic consequences. The movie follows the basic tenet of the book, but differs on some minor points, (certainly, Shmuel looked less like a starved Jew than Bruno did) and I found the plummy English accent a little off-putting. It has a dramatic, Hollywood-style ending.

The perspective of the holocaust through the friendship of two boys, each on a different side of the camp fence, is truly unique.  What was so interesting though was how each character in the film evolved.  Every character's story was told in detail, and the depth of their knowledge of the camp or their naive misconceptions growing to enlightenment was powerful. That evolution was beautifully portrayed by the actors.  The acting was incredible throughout, though I did find the accents of Brits playing German characters a bit distracting. As others have said the ending will leave you completely floored but it drives a stake into your heart of the insanity of the holocaust.

The Blu-ray is DTS 5.1 sound and a perfect transfer of a 1.85:1 aspect ratio.  At the time of this review the BD is almost half the price of the DVD.  It that's the case when you're interested in a purchase, get the blu-ray.
Ordered in July and at this stage have not received so how can I review  the items still waiting when I receive items will than comment

I've read the book upon which this movie is based, and also reviewed it. The book makes for a thoughtful discussion on the Holocaust, though it did have some problems having to do with plot implausibilities. Yet despite all of that, I did think the book added some value to novels dealing with the Holocaust, especially in portraying the story from the 8-year-old German Aryan boy's point of view.

Now on to the movie - the story follows the book closely with some adaptations. Set during WW II, 8-year-old German Aryan, Bruno finds his carefree life in Berlin is about to come to an end as his father [David Thelis] has been promoted to the position of Kommandant thus necessitating the family's move to a rural outpost which is nameless. So, Bruno [Asa Butterfield], his 12-year-old sister Gretel [Amber Beattie], mother [Vera Farmiga] and dad make the move. Bruno is initially not impressed with his new surroundings - there are no other houses nearby and the children are not able to attend school, having to be taught by an old tutor who very much subscribes to Nazi ideology, pummeling the children with his ideology of hatred every chance he gets. Young Bruno in the meantime has discovered a 'farm' close by and to his immense delight, meets another 8-year-old boy with the curious name of Schmuel [Jack Scanlon] who seems to have tons of 'friends' and has the luxury of wearing 'pajamas' all day. Though he is forbidden to explore the back of the house, Bruno makes clandestine visits to his friend, who sadly cannot play with him as they are separated by a barbed wire fence, which Bruno thinks is to keep the animals out. The pairs friendship grows every day, and Bruno begins to discover certain things - that Jews are not treated well [he doesn't really buy the "Jews are evil" idea], and begins to see his father in a different light [the Kommandant keeps silent when a Jewish houseworker is pummeled by a sadistic Nazi underling]. In the meantime, Bruno's mother Ilse [Vera Farmiga] begins to fall apart as she comes to discover what really goes on in the camps [extermination of Jews] and suffers an emotional breakdown. The rest of the story deals with what happens to Bruno and Schmuel and the others.

There are some plot implausibilities - the fact that Bruno is so incredibly naive about Jews and the ideology of hatred against them is hard to accept if only because most German Aryan boys of Bruno's age would have been in the Hitler Youth and thus exposed to such teachings. Bruno being a high-ranking Nazi officer's son would most certainly have been in the Hitler Youth as would his sister. Also, Ilse not knowing of what was going on in the camp [extermination] also seems implausible. As for Schmuel, most young children were immediately selected for the gas chambers upon arrival, and it seems almost miraculous that Schmuel survived for as long as he did, and was able to meet Bruno so often without detection.

But, implausibilities aside, I still liked this movie - it manages to portray the innocence of children in a depraved world so very credibly, and this is largely due to Asa Butterfield's amazing performance as the naive Bruno whose eyes are slowly 'opened' to the cruelty evident around him. Jack Scanlon's Schmuel is also credible -the chemistry between the two boys is very real, and their friendship is altogether believable, even the part when Bruno 'betrays' his friend and Schmuel's reaction to this. Vera Farmiga's performance as the tormented Ilse is the most powerful adult performance in this movie - she delivers a finely-nuanced performance that makes us believe Ilse was truly horrified by what was being done to the Jews. The other adult male characters delivered rather weak performances - David Thewlis as the Kommandant was stiff in his role and seemed ill at ease for the most part, the sadistic Nazi driver seemed very much a one-dimensional character, and even the Jewish houseworker was not given much character development.

All in all, "Boy in the Striped Pajamas" succeeds in getting under one's skin and doesn't cop out with a happily ever after ending, for the climax is brutal and mind-numbing. The child actors' powerful performances enables the movie to address questions about humanity and man's capacity for evil.
This more really shows you how innocent children are. These boys become friends during WWII and they come from different worlds. I thought this moving was very inspiring.

I had not expected this movie to be this good, or for the boys to do such an incredible job acting that they dragged you right in.

I served in the military, and spent almost 5 years in Germany, and have gone and visited camps.  And even all the years after the fact, you can still almost feel the horror and despair.  Simply visiting was a horrific experience, because the whole time you are there, you can't help but try to imagine what it was like.  Anyone with the sensitivity of a caterpillar ends up overwhelmed with compassion and loss, numbed and unable to encompass the magnitude of the reality.

In all the things I've seen regarding the camps, I've never seen, or even imagined, a story about it portrayed through the eyes of an 8 year old child.  And not just an 8 year old child inside the camp, but an 8 year old child who is outside of it, innocent of what is going on while his father is the German running the camp.  An 8 year old who befriends a Jewish boy interred in the camp his father runs, neither really understanding the full reality.  And watching as the little German boy starts to wonder, to question, to learn that the lies he was fed were just that, lies.

Watching the story unfold, drawing you along with it, starting out so innocently, and seeing as the people who were unaware start to become aware...  It was masterfully done.  I have to get the book now.

Such a simple premise for a story, but such a powerful one.  It's one of those movies that will be with you for a long time...
I received this movie about a week ago but hadn't yet viewed it. After reading the above review I thought it best to check my copy. It is Blu-Ray and it runs perfectly on my Oppo 93.

This is a gut-wrenching movie that illustrates the horror of the holocaust and the Nazi machine that turned the world inside-out.  The story includes all of the elements of an engaging, provoking movie. It leads to a tragic climax that truly brings home the devastation of the evil that millions in the world swore never to forget.

I think the PG-13 rating is correct. It is quite disturbing due to the events -- not to anything too graphic.

This movie (and the book to a greater extent)is a much-watch. Yeah, I know that there's some serious inaccuracies (in real life there were more prisoners, the kid would have been murdered at his arrival at the camp, and German citizens weren't clueless about the Final Solution) but the overall point is still pertinent. It's not too often that we see the Holocaust from the perspective of a child, and that point of view illustrates that the way racists categorize human beings is wrong. Since Bruno is so innocent, the irrationality of the Nazis is striking. Personally, I liked the book better because it emphasized his innocence which made the end much more shocking.

 ******POSSIBLE SPOILER*****
The best part is that when they're dressed the same, it's impossible to tell the boys apart even though one is from the 'master race' and the other is an 'eeeevil' Jew. In the book it's even better because Bruno has a shaved head. How can a person be inhuman if they look like a human when they're dressed like one?

A Poem I wrote after seeing this film. I was substitute teaching in
a sixth grade classroom for a few days and the students asked me
to watch the movie.

I watched a movie early last night,
a movie sixth graders had asked me to view.
Should I or could I or would I
have watched a movie such as this anytime sooner than now?
Well, I've seen Schlinder's List
and I applauded his try.
Then tonight I again viewed a movie with a tear in my eye
because I remember when I was 17
and on a European study trip into Germany we went.
I guess to view a living history
that only 19 years earlier was still alive and ill.
The showers with no water I walked through.
The brick buildings with all the ovens
for 1 or 2 or maybe a few.
The open ditches for men, women, and children.
Yes, those holy burial grounds I found.
I remember my pain, my shock, my disbelief.
I had read The Diary of Anne Frank,
but nothing makes an impression quite like the real thing.
I feel kind of sick right now and so to my words and piano I must go.
Dear, dear hearts:  my precious little friends who asked me to watch this film,
I hope and pray you will always choose somewhere good to go
and something good to do because reality can be very, very hard to see.

I read my review to that class I was substituting in the following day.

WOW!!  Amazing.  Great movie about the concentrations camps told through the innocent eyes of an 8 year old boy.  I highly recommend this movie....one of the most moving, well acted movies I've seen in a long time!

I finished this book in one sitting. I enjoyed reading it. I have always been interested in stories regarding the Holocaust and I think it is important to keep our youth educated on the topic. I do not want to spoil any part of the book, but I became frustrated with the main character Bruno towards the end of the book because of his "stupidity" I would call it. However, I thought that the ending to the book really showed how children can be so naive and innocent and do anything for a friend. I would recommend this book to someone. Cannot wait to see the movie.

This is a very moving movie. It touches every piece of your heart! I could not hold back the tears for both boys in this movie! These two children actors were GREAT and should have won an award. I give this this movie 5 stars and although I don't think it was based on actual facts, it was based on actual facts of what happened in the most terrible times of that terrible war with Hitler in control. This movie is for anyone who really wants to see a movie that is extraordinary in touching your heart. The picture quality is also great in the dvd. Thanks Amazon for another great dvd!

Not to spoil this wonderful moving story but after growing up with a substantial Jewish population in my neighborhood and seeing that number tattoo on so many arms and having an anti semetic father this film shows how a Nazi officer takes a promotion to the countryside to run a concentration camp with his family. Naturally the children miss all friends in the city and the family is told by the father that it is a "work farm" after the son spies it from a window and asks. He later sneaks away to the farm and meets a boy through the fence in Striped Pajamas. Living in such a remote and rural area the Commanders family lives in a house that is too far from school and is guarded around the clock with labor camp prisoners doing menial tasks on the property. The boy starts sneaking to the camp and develops a friendship with the other boy in the striped pajamas like any young boys do. They sit and talk, read through the fence in a blind spot arrange for lack of a better term play dates. The boy in the striped pajamas never reveals what really happens when the showers happen. The commanders father has no knowledge of his sons friendship or the fact he smuggles food over to his secret friend. As the commanders son want's to go into the camp and help his friend do his chores really fast so they can play together without the fence between him. They are determined to have fun after he can leave the farm, all the while keeping the secret. The Mother becomes sympathetic towards the workers who come to visit but must not be seen performing random acts of kindness in Hitlers Germany. So many friends have borrowed this DVD from me and purchased it themselves.

i've read some of these review where people seem to be confused by whether this is supposed to be aimed at kids, or aimed at adults and fails due to the reliance on Bruno's point of view. I think this film is actually an adult film and by having it seen through the eyes of an 8 year old boy helps to remind adults, and anyone over the age of 8, what such events might look like from his point of view. I was a little reluctant to see this, actually, and was a bit conflicted about the "idealization" aspect of it, but having watched the whole film now, it seems that that "lead-up" was necessary. Yes, Bruno was ignorant, but he was only 8! The ending shocked and horrified me, as it should. Of course I wanted his father to rush in and save everyone at the last minute. But for the film that this is, the ending was appropriate. This is not an adult, sweeping, complex, saga. But i do think it was an effective film -- not quite sure what the whole point of Rupert Friend's character was, except to very effectively be the very very "scary soldier" who is the closest in proximity to Bruno. Would recommend it, but not to anyone under 10 or 12.

This movie captures the intense need for normalcy admist the chaos. It focuses on a family whose father happens to be in charge of a concentration camp. Their son is curious and adventurous like any boy his age. He stumbles upon the camp but doesn't understand what it is and befriends a boy his own age on the other side of the fence. The acting is superb and the focus on non-verbal communication, i.e. face expression & body language, is what really sets this film apart.

A very well done movie with a twist at the end. The horrors of World War 2 and the concentration camps will not be forgotten, yet this movie goes about it with from a slightly different point of view, but the results are the same, in any war there are casualties and the loss of life are tragic for any and all family members on either side of the conflict.

The film will capture your hearts and souls, putting you on the edge of you seat throughout. You will, no doubt, feel all the emotion that will seem to flow from your screen into your heart. Amazing film.

This is a great movie, very touching and heartwarming (up to a certain point), about a tough and ugly subject - concentration camps during World War II. A young boy whose father is a commander in the Army comes upon another little boy wearing striped pajamas inside a fenced compound. The boy thinks the people wearing pajamas are all farmers with glorious lives (as portrayed by the soldiers), not understanding what is really happening to these people. It's a sad and profound story through the eyes of a child about the consequences of war and what we choose when we alienate any group of people based upon race, religion, or creed.

Rated PG-13 (I believe) for harsh theme, some violence.

I went into watching this movie knowing the storyline and knowing all about the Holocaust, I grew up in a Jewish family knowing all the terror of what happend with Hitler's rein during World War II.  This movie helped me explain to my 10 year old daughter about the good and bad and people.  Ironically she compared this movie to the slaves of the Civil War, however as I told her the Slaves were treated much better than the Jewish people during World War II.  This movie from start to finish is incredible, I did cry at the end of this movie for I had heard of the endinng prior to watching the movie, and I had heard of the horror of the work camps first hand from friends who were in Europe during Hitler's rein.  Sadly after watching this, I do wonder why no member of The Academy never acknowledged this film.  The actors were all first class, the screen play was great.  I just wish the movie wasn't based upon a true scenario of the 20th century.  This movie helps heal those who lost loved ones and helps us explain to our young children of the 21st century this should never happen again.  This movie is a must see for anyone trying to explain to children the awful rein of Adolph Hitler and his followers.

This movie is really good and everyone in my family liked it. It's very sad but really gives you an idea of what life was like for the Jews in concentration camps. I would also recommend the book.  This is one of my favorite movies.
A very moving story about the relationship between two young boys - one Jewish and one German - during World War II.

This is an amazing movie. Although it didn't get much recognition, it definitely deserves it. Bruno, the 9-year-old son of an SS officer, who was moved to the countryside, next to a concentration camp, is completely oblivious to everything that is going around him. He seems somewhat naive - almost a little too naive, when everything around him is against Jews and for the Nazis. He makes friends with one Shmuel, a boy in the concentration camp, wearing 'striped pajamas,' who lives in the 'farm.' Bruno thinks Shmuel is lucky, being able to 'play' with so many friends and to wear 'pajamas' all day. He sneaks food and games for Shmuel, and eventually begins to learn about the differences between him and the people behind the fence.

If you are planning to read the book as well, the book is more seen through the eyes of a young child. The movie is definitely for an older audience, and show Bruno's family more as a unit than the book does.

Although the it's rated PG-13, it might not seem like it at the beginning. The subject that this movie is dealing with is very delicate, but I think that the director did a great job of handling it. Although the movie never explicitly shows what happens to Bruno and Shmuel - you can find that out for yourself - you get the gist of it, and I think that is the worst part - not in a bad way! The movie really makes you think and gives a lot of food for thought. Be forewarned, tears will come! The book and movie are slightly different, but they are both worth taking a look at. There is a great message to be learned in the movie, like the subtitle says: innocence lost, humanity found. The ending of the movie is extremely sad, but the message is very powerful and you will not be disappointed.

I had read this book, and thought the movie was wonderful, I felt it was a wonderful way to show my children how the german people thought about the concentration camps, and they saw the typr of propaganda used to make them feel that they were doing the opposite of what they were doing.  I loved this film !

Here we see the in depth study of how a father's work as a Nazi with the Jewish genocide affects his family-particularly a naive son. The son befriends a Jew and is altogether ignorant of the atrocities of the Nazis. The sister is brainwashed with Nazi propaganda and the fake glory of the fuhrer. The mother is indifferent until she is touched by the annihilations of the concentration camps and no longer wants to see how her husband is involved. And the husband/father is the picture of a high-ranking officer with a a cold attitude who does his "duty" in the line of a patriotic Nazi to the "Fatherland".

I watched this movie after wanting to see if for a while. I actually loved it from the trailer, which after watching the actual movie made me love it even more! Bruno was such a sweet little boy who didn't understand what was going on, and didn't want to believe what he was being told about the Jews. He was plainly trying to help his new friend out when his fate got twisted in the horrifying ending. I honestly have not read the book, so I didn't expect the ending at all! It left me in silence, hoping that in my "happily ever after" expectancy of a movie Bruno would cross the screen after somehow miraculously escaping the gas chambers. Nope. It's pretty bad that's what I was waiting for as the screen faded out, and after it went black. But overall, great movie definitely recommend to people!

Outstanding film. 10/10.

What a heartbreaking, brutal example of an important point that unfortunately needs to be reiterated often.

The Holocaust is a testament to what happens when a person dehumanizes someone who they perceive as worthless, a lesser being and/or some kind of threat.

Propaganda is a powerful tool that can fuel the smallest battle - between a few individuals or even the majority of a nation - by convincing them that they need to conquer someone else.

To strip someone of their most basic human rights by enslaving them under the threat of death is the epitome of evil. It's terrifying to know that it has been a reality so many times throughout history. It can happen to anyone.

Racism and narcissism are alive and well. Who are we to decide that someone is less valuable and important than we are based on their appearance, life circumstances, religion or ancestry?
I loved the story. It has a never again feel to it, in the lesson it tells. The acting was top notch inluding that of the children. It is a great and different perspective on the holocaust.

Little Bruno, the son of a Nazi officer, does not understand why the people in his world think Jews are bad. He doesn't understand why a man who's really a doctor is working as a potato peeler in his kitchen. And, he doesn't get why a boy about his age has to stay on the other side of a barbed wire fence and go around in his pajamas all day. But that boy, Shmuel, is the only friend he can find near his new house. Almost every day, Bruno throws his ball out too far "by accident" and runs to get it, as an excuse to run to the barbed wire fence where he spends time with his friend.

Throughout this film, you can get a sense of how much or how little Germans knew about the Holocaust when it was happening. Some had a general idea of what was going on, while others were blind to what their country was doing. On the one extreme, Bruno was almost completely ignorant about what was happening to Jewish people. On the other, his dad and his dad's coworkers were the ones exterminating. Bruno's sister grew to be more nationalistic and pro-Nazi as the story continues, and his mom wasn't a fan of Jews but also couldn't live with the grief that her husband was murdering them in cruel and unusual ways. Because of his mom's sentiments, Bruno, his mom, and sister were going to go live with relatives in Heidelberg. But something happens that gets in the way of a peaceful transit to the city.

This movie is NOT based on a true story; however, it is still just as dark and tragic as many of the other popular films about the Holocaust, maybe even more so. Anyone who has liked watching movies like The Pianist and Schindler's List should see this one! I saw the commentaries and deleted scenes too. The actors and crew who were interviewed explained their roles and related it to the way people like their character in 1940s Germany must have felt. The deleted scenes include Bruno seeing the concentration camp from his window, and his maid looking for him. They are very minor parts and not really amazing, but I guess that's why they're deleted scenes.

I have two small complaints against the movie. One is that all the characters have a British accent! Yes, most of the actors were of British descent, but it didn't make any sense in the context of the movie! Also, it is a bit unrealistic that a German and Jewish boy are able to meet at the fence all the time, without a soldier punishing at least the Jewish one. Despite these two imperfections, it really is a great movie.
The DVD arrived as stated. I have not watched it yet but everyone says it is a very moving film so I am looking forward to watching it (with hankies Ive been advised)
Excellent movie, with an unexpected ending. Remember. God has promised to bless those who bless the Jews. Bless you Bruno!

What was most memorable about this movie is that even when people understood what was happening, and were adamantly opposed to it, they still did nothing about it. The grandmother in the movie was obviously aware and opposed from the beginning, but said almost nothing. There is some question about what really happened to her in the movie, but she was such a peripheral character I can't write much about it.

 The mother in the film was such a coward when she understood the horror of the camp, yet still allowed her children to be indoctrinated by their tutor. When she saw her daughter with a crush on an especially cold and cruel young officer, she never tried to dissuade her daughter from forming an attachment. When a prisoner showed her son kindness and took care of him when he was hurt, all she could manage was a perfunctory, unemotional word of thanks. And when that same prisoner lost his life for a simple mishap, she said not one word as he was killed. She did fight with her husband about it, but she could have done so much more.

 I think, as a mother myself, the character of the mother in this story was a tragic figure because of her lack of words and action to do anything to even make the life of the prisoners (two were in the house during the movie) even a little bit better. A kind word, an offering of food--but no, she did not do one single thing. Then, at the end of the movie, she suffered what no mother should suffer and partially because of her apathy of evil.

 The acting in this movie is excellent (although it is odd that every person seems to have a British/Irish accent--definitely not German or Polish--which is distracting to the authenticity of the story) from the children (how do young people become so talented at such young ages?) to the adults. Every character is important to the movie, but the character of the mother is most memorable to me.

I would recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in history (just try to ignore the accents) and would like an unusual story of that time from a different perspective, as seen from a children's eyes, from both sides of the barbed wire.
Excellent movie in terms of storyline, photography and importance. Definetly a movie you will not forget. Brilliant!!!!

This is a very moving movie about a very hard time in our world's history. It is the story of two boys, in very different situations, which learn the value of friendship and the hate and destruction the human race can bring onto others. I highly recommend this movie for anyone wanting to insure that they never forget the tragedies of the Holocaust. I also highly recommend the book "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas" by John Boyne.

The story of the friendship between these two young boys is so touching.  The young actors who portray them are excellent. The story is incredible...funny, sad, touching, frightening.

I recommend this movie to everyone who cares.
This is one of the best movies. Everything about it made for easy viewing. No gratuitous violence or sex or language. Exceptional for family viewing.

Only the previews of other movies play on the DVD Boy in the stripped pajamas will play. The feature presentation itself will not play. I contacted the sellers and was told to clean it with alcohol and it still does not work. The is no movie on the DVD.

Yvonne Casen

This has got to be one of the best movies I've ever seen.  For me, this was not only an exceptional film involving the Holocaust and World War II, but an incredibly moving and emotional tale of a friendship that developed that knew no prejudice or intolerance. Those involved in the the creation and operation of concentration camps often had housing for themselves and their family close by.  How haunting to have your family living in close proximity to where so much torture and death was being carried out.  Karma can be cruel and this is played out in a chilling fashion.  I do NOT want to include any information that could serve as a spoiler, so I ask you trust that the film will not disappoint.  This was film on the scale of "Schindler's List" in terms of the impact of the story and the connection of the characters with the audience.  The film will stick with you long after the credits have stopped rolling.  A five star must see recommendation.

I think that this movie rather focuses on childhood and that the historic context is less important, yet very dramatic.
It is about the dangerous games children play, and it might have been set anywhere anytime where the grown-ups are in war.
Wonderful, shocking movie. I couldn't breathe at the end.

The film juxtaposed the beautiful with the ugly in a very quiet and intelligent manner.  The holocaust was depicted more visually than with dialogue, I thought.  There are several scenes which reminded us of the ghastly photographs of the holocaust.  The music was beautiful but thoroughly haunting.  We expected a sad ending but we were stunned when we saw it.  My family sat in silence, heartsick with grief.  This film makes its point of how sick and depraved a society can become. I feel this is an important film for all to see as it is one of the best films I've ever seen on the subject.

This movie is extradinary! Two children caught-up during WWII in Germany. One boy, Jewish, behind fences and in a camp; the other a German boy - both the same age. Neither understands anything that is going on. The German boy thinks the Jewish boy plays games in the camp because his has numbers on his pajamas. The two boys are so innocent. The ending will knock you socks off. You will be crying and yelling out loud "No, no, no way"!!! I give this movie 5 stars. One of the best, most heart-felt, movies I have ever seen; and believe me, I have seen almost every movie since I was 16 and I'm now 60.  Buy it. You won't regret it. You will definitely learn more about life, people, children, horrible crimes, and the truth about the war.

The Boy In The Striped Pajamas is yet another take on the horrors of the holocaust. So many horrors, I'd venture to say, that a hundred more books and movies could be made about it. Although I was born in America and was never  personally touched by the Holocaust, in a way I actually was. As a child I saw the horrific photos of piles of emaciated bodies lying in heaps and it colored my world. I think at that moment I knew how the world was and I became an Athiest on the spot and gratefully stayed one. I never want to believe in a God that would or could let that happen for any reason. It still bothers me when people (usually Christians or other religious people} think that God personally caters to them when there are people laying in the dirt somewhere starving to death. Same with the Holocaust. Why would God do this or that, but let the Holocaust happen? The ability to live your life with blinders on must be nice, but that is what happened on a monumental scale in Germany. And this film, as flawed as it is, is yet another chilling example of what happens when you do. The movie is well made. Great music, acting, attention to detail, except for one very glaring fact. Yes, it was set in Germany, but everyone has a distinct English accent. Even the strawberry blond evil Nazi youth has a distinct English accent, as do the Jews in the concentration camp. There isn't a German accent to be found anywhere. Maybe someone on the movie set had one, but no one in the movie does, which I think has a detrimental effect on the whole thing. I couldn't help but think about England during this period. They were being terrorized by Hitler too, yet the movie has the good guys and the bad guys all speaking with English accents. It was hard to get past and a little unsettling. English accents are, for lack of a better word, usually pretty. The actors accents gave the whole movie a genteel feel, which a Holocaust movie should never have. Funny no one who has reviewed this film mentioned the English accents because I kept waiting for the Nazis to have a tea party. It drained the movie of true menace and made it seem unrealistic. If it weren't for the performances of the two boys and the mother, the movie really could have sunk in my opinion... that is until the ending, which is absolutely chilling. I was stunned and had to recover from it. But afterwards it made me realize how badly I wanted what preceded it, to have even half the impact the ending does. It was so good, but it could have been nearly perfect with a little tweeking.
This is such a sweet movie.  Keep a box of Kleenex close by. I had my teen grandchildren watch and they were touched.  I kept renting it and finally just bought it through Amazon.

Gut the film of a few clichés and the unintentional humor (some of their more obvious attempts at subtle statements come across slightly amusing) and you'd have a near perfect example of the gritty realities of human weakness.  Yes, the Holocaust, one of the most brutal and overall disgusting `black spots' in human history is given a fresh take in this spellbinding and heartbreaking tale about a young boy oblivious to the horrors his specious is capable of.

Makes you sick just thinking about it.

The film follows a young boy named Bruno who moves with his family to the countryside.  His father, a high ranking official in the SS troops, has been promoted and so the move is necessary.  Bruno is less than enthused about leaving his friends, but upon arriving at his new home (which is beautiful) he notices a farm out in the distance, and there are children working in the farm.  From the looks of them, they are strange to him, but he is curious.  Despite his parents concern with his venturing `out back', Bruno (who is obsessed with adventure books) decides to sneak away and find the farm.  When he gets there he meets a young boy named Shmuel (pronounced almost like `small').  Young Bruno (and to a degree Shmuel) are oblivious to the truth about the farm.  Bruno is taught that Jews are disgusting people who are less than human and that they are responsible for the fall of German society.  He is also misguided into thinking that the Jews are being properly cared for.  Shmuel is kept in the dark about the eventualities about his stay at the farm.  The two boys strike a friendship and a bond that transcends society's boundaries.

If only we could all be as innocent as children.

That was one of the main things I gathered from this movie.  I loved the way that it brilliantly captured the forgiving and understanding quality that children possess.  They can see through to the heart of a person.  Even after young Bruno betrays his friend, causing him serious harm, Shmuel forgives him almost instantly, understanding that Bruno was not malicious or hurtful but merely frightened and acted without thinking.  If they had been adults, it would have most likely resulted in a longstanding grudge and retaliation.

Another point I gathered from this film, a point I think is remarkably strong, is that not every German completely understood or even agreed with what was taking place.  The character of Elsa, the mother, in particular is a strong one.  She was a woman who was brainwashed by a nation to believe in a `cause' that was horrific in itself, but when she discovered what was being done to the Jews at that farm she was mortified.  It destroyed her.  She was raised to hate them and to believe that they were the enemy, but she was not evil enough to forget that they were human beings.

I'm shocked at the poor reception this film garnered, but then again I think many people viewed this as a children's film, which it is not.  In fact, unless you want to answer a lot of uncomfortable and difficult questions, I'd keep the kids FAR away from this movie.

That said, the film is borderline genius to be honest.  I mean, I can see the films few flaws and there are some areas I wish were cleaned up a tad, but overall this film simply has everything it needs.  From the brilliant performances (Vera Farmiga is a goddess and young Asa Butterfield probably should have been nominated for an Oscar) to the beautiful sets and stunning camera work to the chilling screenplay that uses a fresh perspective to twist the knife a tad deeper, `The Boy in the Striped Pajamas' is a stunning film that truly deserves to be seen and discussed.

The Mrs. and I just rewatched Schindler's List (Widescreen Edition) and that masterpiece made us interested in the recent "Boy in the Striped Pajamas". Have you not often wondered what the good people of Germany were thinking as Hitler codified anti-Semitism and six million Jews were murdered? This film shows that not everyone was in lock-step with the mindless prejudices that would allow otherwise "good" people who looked the other way while unspeakable evil walked the earth, but the evil viewpoint was the one that prevailed. Bruno (Asa Butterfield) is much like other eight year old boys. He is curious and loves his family. His family provides a comfortable home and a loving environment. Bruno's father is a soldier, and Bruno takes some pride seeing his father in his uniform. Bruno's father is receiving a promotion and an assignment to an important new post. At the new assignment Bruno sees workers at the farm where his father is the overseer. Curious - all the workers wear dull black and white striped pajamas. If we know even a little about the holocaust, it is curious to see if through the eyes of eight-year-old Bruno. Bruno is lonely in his new home - there are no other young children. On the other side of the barbed wire his new friend, Shmuel, has the opportunity to play with the other workers. We see the horror as Bruno's mother (played by Vera Farmiga) realizes that dear old Dad is the kommandant of a Death Camp rather than a work camp. She is horrified, and like the Kommandant's mother, not in agreement with the "final solution". But their voices are in the minority, and drowned out by the prevailing opinion of the inherent "evilness" of the Jews. This film does not break new story-telling ground. But by telling the story from a point of view that we rightly expect to be innocent, and shielded from horror - we feel the horror more nearly than from an history book. In scope and tone and story and setting and cinematography inferior to Speilberg's masterpiece, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is nonetheless a worthwhile film.

This truly, from a historical standpoint, is one of the most ridiculous movies I have ever seen.  From this movie I learned the following "facts."
1.  Auschwitz is apparently in Germany.
2.  Auschwitz except for one barrack, didn't have very many prisoners.  It also wasn't very crowded.
3.  Apparently, except for one fly buzzing in the background, sanitation wasn't that bad.
4.  Prisoners were of a healthy weight.
5.  Except for in the barrack, there were literally no guards.
6.  Auschwitz had no guard towers.
7.  If you wanted, you could chat with prisoners of Auschwitz anytime you wanted just be walking up to the barbed wire.
8.  Full grown men were gassed and young children were gassed only when they accidentally got mixed in with the full grown men.  Otherwise, young children were okay.
9.  If you wanted in to Auschwitz, simply dig a hole under the fence and nobody will mind.
10.  There were only men in Auschwitz and no women.

I could go on and on with the ridiculous historical inaccuracies, but those are my top 10 problems.  If you are looking for a movie that romanticizes history, then you are fine.  It is a movie that can make you think about the ending.  However, since most people don't know enough about the Holocaust already, I worry that they are going to take this movie to be fact, when it is nowhere close.
I've seen this movie at least 3 times and enjoyed it.  I enjoyed the "making of" too.
Excellent choice - I bought this as a gift and it arrived within 3 business days.

This movie deserves way more credit than it has been given! Unfortunate events surrounding the time of World War II are portrayed in both blatant and subtle ways from the 8 year-old Bruno's perspective. He remains oblivious to the turbulence of the politics and war. He can see signs of violence (treatment of Pavel by the soldier, treatment of the soldier by Bruno's own father, the 'horrible smell' etc) but he is too young to guess or understand exactly what is going on. He makes friends with a Jewish boy Shmuel in the 'farm' and joins him to find Schmuel's missing father. He meets his death along with untold number of people in the 'shower room'.

It is for the movie watcher to decide if Bruno's father, the administrator of the 'farm' learned his lesson as a human being. Many such scenes in the movie provoke the audience to think and rethink. The 'soft' side of Bruno's father comes to light when he, upon insistence of his wife, decides to send his children away from the 'camp' area. But it is too late-the movie ends with the tough but grief-stricken father standing still at the shock of his son's murder. As tragic as it is, it is a very powerful presentation.

I also have seen many movies about the Holocaust, and this one stands out immensely, by quietly showing the apathy and deceit required of supposedly civilized people, shown in different ways by Bruno's parents. I have read a number of comments that think Bruno was more than a little dim for not getting it, while supposedly Bruno's mother knew nothing about what was really going on at the camps, and I read no comments on that. It would be interesting to me to read an account, an honest account, of what it was like for a Nazi family and how they lived, knowing what was going on. A child knows only what they have been taught, they believe their parents more than anyone in the world, and since all Bruno was told was lies, of course he is going to believe them and want to believe them. He struggled with wanting to love and honor his father and starting to doubt him. The child was only eight! Even though he was seeing the camp with his own eyes, he didn't really know what was going on, no child who had been sheltered and deceived would. The same with Gretel, who also only knew what they wanted her to know, and had not the experience to know better. The Hitler Youth was immensely successful in indoctrination of the children because they are so vulnerable and impressionable.

 I was sickened when the elderly man was beaten to death in front of the children and no one moved a muscle, and I seriously suspected the actual cause of the grandmother's death, bombing or not, since she was vocally opposed to the Reich. I feared for the life and health of Bruno's mother as well, and don't think the father, brutal and committed to the Reich, would just let her walk away with his children.

The ending was immensely powerful, yet I wanted it to have impact on the father other than just personally, otherwise, I didn't see the point. The worst monster can love his child.

I don't think it was Auschwitz, which held thousands of people. This one seemed very small, more like a work camp, and not all of them were killing camps, other than by starvation and disease, etc.

The boy that played Schmuel was the sweetest boy and his scenes just broke my heart.

A touching story of two boys-a son of concentration camp commandant and a same aged Jewish inmate, their relations and revenge. An extremely romantic, multy-purposed work luckily short of modern musical-type comedian features Life Is Beautiful presents. Highly recommended family viewing in HAMAS-supportive areas especially.

So far, I've only viewed this riveting film twice. But it doesn't take too many viewings to evoke much commentary on this memorable historical drama.
  Based on the book of the same name by John Boyne, it deals with the story of young Bruno (whose wide-blue-eyed innocence is played outstandingly by young Asa Butterfield), the eight-year-old son of a member of the German High Command (David Thewlis)in World War II Berlin.
 We meet Bruno and his family as they learn they are to move to Poland due to the promotion of Bruno's father. The young boy frolics with his friends in the streets, oblivious to people being rounded up and herded into cattle cars around them. His beautiful, amiable mother(Vera Farmiga) arrives home from an outing, while his sister, Gretl(Amber Beattie) plays with dolls in her room.
 The children of priviledge soon present themselves downstairs at a party celebrating their father's promotion. In contrast to their grandfather's (Richard Johnson) support of the Third Reich, their grandmother's (Sheila Hancock) apprehension about its policies is noted on this occasion.
 Once in Poland, Bruno finds himself without any friends, and forbidden to explore certain parts of the new residence.
  Soon, he sneaks out anyway, and encounters the mysterious "farm" he was able to see from his bedroom window before it was boarded up.
  He encounters a young boy in striped pajamas named Schmuel(Jack Scanlon)and begins to converse with him, gradually beginning to empathize with his plight.
  At home, he sees the Nazi Lieutenant Kotler(Rupert Friend), amusing his sister, and brutalizing a Jewish servant named Pavel (David Hayman, who was previously in another WWII flick, "Hope and Glory"), and is curious as to why no one objects to this behavior.
  Over time, as they receive the standard indoctrination from their tutor, Herr  Liszt (Jim Norton), and Gretel becomes a hard-core little Bundist, forsaking her dolls and assuming what she considers to be more appropriate duties in the wake of the Fatherland's plight, while her brother, who seems to have his mother's gentler nature, is more reluctant to accept indoctrination.
  He still visits Schmuel at the edge of the fence whenever possible, occasionally taking him food, passing him his soccer ball, or indulging in a game of checkers, allowing the incarcerated lad to call the moves from his side of the fence. The joy and innocence of these two boys shines amid the horror.
  A bombing claims the life of Bruno's ailing grandmother, and Bruno discusses her funeral with his friend.
  There is an unfortunate moment of betrayal when the sadistic Lieutenant Kotler, perhaps striving to prove his loyalty to the Reich, especially when it becomes known that his father does not support it, catches the two boys together, as Schmuel(who has replaced the murdered Pavel) was cleaning glassware in Bruno's house, and Bruno denies having given Schmuel the sweets he was caught with.
 But Bruno will find a way to reconcile with his friend, in a devastatingly heroic  way that reveals his parents' ultimate failure to shield him from the goings-on, and reveals how terrible poetic justice can be. The last scene of two boys together is one of them clinging to each other among a forest of emaciated adults, looking upward with still-wide-eyed innocence, still believing in the best...
 While there have been complaints about historical accuracy, this is a tale of painful sweetness with a tug at the heartstrings that has the strength of a child's pull, and a reminder of how we may condemn those we love the best with our own hatreds.

Much has been about this film here, mostly pro, some con.  I can only add my opinion that it was a marvelous and riveting film that every kid in the world should watch.  Yes, at times it seemed hard to believe that these two boys, so marvelously acted by Asa Butterfield and Jack Scanlon, could have been so naive.  But they were just eight years old living through something that the rest of the world had not imagined until after they discovered the truth.  If the film is not totally true to history (and I am not commenting on its historical accuracy one way or the other), it nonetheless makes a marvelous story. The ending is a stunner and completely unexpected.  This is a film that, with some preparation, you can show to your pre-teen:  no foul language, no sex, and no in-your-face violence even though the story is set in the most violent era in world history.

As to those critics who heap vituperation on this film because they deny the holocaust occurred, I can only say things to them that would get this review deleted.  I will only say that my father helped liberate a concentration camp, and he did not imagine what he saw.  He did, however, have difficulty discussing it even years later.

My one criticism is why the producers did not include the deleted scenes they present on the DVD.  The movie is barely 1:30 long.  These scenes, all short, would have added little length to the film and would have clarified some issues.  When, for example, I saw the pile of dolls in the basement, I did conclude they were Gretel's, a fact one of the deleted scenes would have explained.  One of them also explains why Bruno, once denied permission to go into the back garden at all, was able to do so with impunity.  We also learn where he got the idea of the extermination camp being a "farm."
I was expecting more than a simple DVD branded for public use. The learning aids are actually on the DVD. You'll have to print them out. Good stuff.

Have you ever watched a movie and then said, "Wow, that was a great movie!" but then realize it seems weird to say that about "this" movie?  This is one of those.  It is not a "happily ever after" ending movie, but it is very touching. I have not read the book, but I do intend to.

My wish is for everyone to see this movie...The holocaust is something that none of us ever forget, as it can happen right here in America also...It was a very moving, emotional movie, one that I won't forget, as I know its true to life...

"The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is an unusual story of the Holocaust.  Bruno (Butterfield) is an eight-year-old boy living in Nazi Germany.  In fact, Bruno's life is great:  he lives in a big house, playing with friends, and enjoying life to the fullest.  His father (Thewlis) is a German officer, and the entire family is proud of him.  That pride grows even larger when the father, an SS officer, gets promoted; a move that requires the entire family to move east to the "countryside".

The first signs that there might be something wrong emerge as Bruno peeks through the window of his room, looking at the strange farmers who all wear pajamas.  Bruno doesn't understand why, upon his inquiry of the strangely dressed people, his window is boarded up, and Bruno is not allowed to play in the back yard.  It is even more strange that one of these farmers works in Bruno's family's kitchen, peeling potatoes and never speaking or even looking up.  Bruno does not understand why this man is peeling the potatoes after he finds out that the man is doctor by training, after Bruno fell and hurt himself.

In fact, Bruno does not know that he is living immediately next to Auschwitz and that his father is the Camp commander.  With the typical curiosity of a child, Bruno goes into the thin strip of forest behind his house, and goes all the way to the barbed wire, behind which he encounters a boy his own age; this boy also wore striped pajamas.  The two boys, unaware of the politics, religion, or ancient hatreds, strike up a friendship, each boy lonely and starving for companionship.  And although separated by the barbed wire, the boys look forward to Bruno's sneaking out of the back yard, and to having simple conversations every day.  But Bruno must be careful lest his parents, or one of their mean uniformed soldier friends find out about Bruno's activities.

I didn't know what to think about this film.  Heaven knows I have seen many films about the Holocaust, and while each offers something new, there are only so many ways a story could be told.  However, I had to take into account that the story of Bruno is fictional.  The film blew me away.  No, there were no great special effects or super tragic scenes sparkled throughout the movie.  No, the film is made in a very simple manner, which only adds charm to it.  What got me is the irony of the film, especially in the very end.  The screenwriting is simple, photography good, and editing well done.  Acting is a bit stiff, but Butterfield did a good job in his role.  In the end, the movie left me perplexed and deep in thought, a result that I often yearn for.

All in all, "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a well-done movie with a controversial ending.  One either loves it or hates it, but it doesn't leave the viewer non-chalant.  Highly recommended.

*Film viewed via Netflix streaming, hence no special features review.

*** This review also published on Epinions.
This movie was wonderful.  It touched my heart that in the eyes of children we are all the same.  When we become adults we forget the simple things that was there when we were children.

I originally got this film because I had seen the excellent actor rupert friend in THE YOUNG VICTORIA and i read that he had played a role as a Nazi soldier in this film...... this film is the poignant story of the German officer's son who was told not to go through the forest and of course he did so and found an "encampment" surrounded by barbed wire and a boy around his age on the other side of the fence. The boy behind the fence is wearing striped pajamas and tells him that the soldiers took his other clothes so he has to wear pajamas now.....a friendship ensues..............THIS FILM IS A "MUST SEE" ABSOLUTELY!!!!!!!!

Of all films made about the Holocaust and the horror of it this film stands out. The story grabs you and you can't but think about it long after the film has finished. The two boys are superb in making the characters believable. I truly recommend it.

A friend of mine had rented this movie because her son had watched part of it and suggested she get it. I had never heard of it, and I got only a minimal synopsis of it before watching it, because my friend didn't really know what it was about either. I don't want to totally spoil the movie, so I will just say... I was NOT expecting the outcome of the movie. I remember thinking as I was watching it that this certain scenario would play out... I totally didn't. So, be warned.... This is a great movie. Totally moving. But, it's intense in the end.

There were so many things taught in this movie. The total innocence of one child and the age and wisdom of another child of the same age. Knowing the history of the period. Sometimes we forget we can still learn something NEW. From a perspective it breaks our heart to think of THE CHILDREN.

The innocent son of a high-ranking Nazi commandant, Bruno has been largely shielded from the harsh realities of the war. When Bruno discovers that his father has been promoted and that their family will be moving from Berlin into the countryside, he doesn't take the news well. Increasingly bored in his sprawling yet dreary country abode and forbidden by his mother from exploring the backyard, young Bruno searches for something to do while his older sister plays with dolls and vies for the attention of handsome Lieutenant Kotler. One day, bored and gazing out his bedroom window, Bruno spies what first appears to be a nearby farm and his parents refuse to discuss it, and all of the inhabitants there are curiously clad in striped pajamas.  Both young actors give enormously moving performances and the manner in which Herman directs the action underlines the blur of perception many German's had about the reality of the Final Solution. But for what I perceive as the reason this movie sustains the powerful message it does is the manner in which it ends. There are no attempts to 'sanitize' this movie: it simply ends with a lightning bolt jolt that is one of the most powerful statements in all of the many movies about the Holocaust. It is simply a brilliant masterpiece of a movie from every aspect.

Great movie!
Also, the movie was delivered on time and in good condition.
This was a pretty good movie. Ended rather odd though. Kept thinking that the little boys would be found in time. Makes me want to read the book.

Ithink all high school children should read and watch the boy in stripped pajamas, i enjoyed both and have passed it on to many of my friends, I grew up in England during world war 11, I know what its like in war times ,
